a few thoughts on mallari!!!!!! i didn't dislike it but i also didn't love it the way i thought i would. i anticipated its netflix release for a long time and i wish i could say that it was giving everything and more,, but given my misguided, and quite frankly, very steep expectations the only thing i can say right now is that it was extremely promising if only they focused on the structure of the story better and made more practical choices. by practical i mean mostly in terms of the special effects for the creatures and the way they aged the actors. they could have just used prosthetics and other more tangible effects and it would have looked far more believable and less jarring/out of place as opposed to the visual effects that were present throughout the entire material. as for the story!!!!! i really liked the way it enriched and utilized lower mythology and how they incorporated the various time periods in the philippines. the superstitions, mixed with factual elements, and everything in the story comprising and lending filipino-ness to the film was refreshing as opposed to the constant cliches and re-hashing of tired tropes from the west in most horror films we encounter in mainstream filipino media. the antagonist was easy to spot early on in the film, i think it was a mix of the foreshadowing/direction and the acting. perhaps they could have made less obvious choices on both the acting and script to be able to make the reveal less predictable. also there were parts in the script wherein they could have removed the dialogue. too much tell and not enough show!! there were so many unnecessary monologues and it kind of removed me from urgent scenes wherein i would have appreciated just SEEING what the characters were saying out loud. it's a film!!!!! SHOW don't TELL right? the story also only really picked up its pace in the final 1/4 part of the entire running time which is a bummer. honestly it could have been trimmed down if only they removed some unnecessary monologues. if they did this the pacing of the entire film could have been better i think. overall i enjoyed it, i just felt disappointed because it could have been a cinematic masterpiece.

Group Movie Review!Geo: 2/5. I mean what did I expect watching this film. It just feels like such a messy movie to follow and understand what’s happening. It is a promising movie for filipino films, thrill and twist was good. But the ending was just not how we wanted it to end.Z: 2/5. The movie was okay, not worth recommending to people though, the story was messy and it was hard to follow, and the ending sucked.Bhoy: 3/5. The ending is very good. I personally don’t think the ending is okay.K: 4.5/5. Very interesting movie. EYYYJ: 2/5 I thought it would be a normal killer type movie. Then it was about keeping his mother alive by eating humans. and time traveling thorugh dreams.A: 2/5. another day another villainized folk culture while catholicism is made to be the god. Didn't help too that this was set in spanish colonization where spaniards really used folktales to scare people. Feeling ko rin folk culture was used para iparating na kahit papano malinis pa rin konsensya ni Mallari at napilitan lang siya, kumbaga to give him some sort of salvation even if in real life hindi naman ganoon ang nangyari. Half-baked and too questionable din ang motivations ng characters, masyado silang 2D. Di naman magets bakit ulol na ulol siya para isalba si Janella at ang nanay niya. Relationships were established merely on dialogues (told instead of shown) na "gagawin ko lahat maisalba ka lang" pero walang concrete foundation ang motivation niya para makaconnect ang audience sa character ng mga Mallari.Wala ring subtlety, obvious na yung info pero sasabihin pa rin ng characters, para tuloy akong nanonood ng nga skit namin nung high school. Tsaka bakit ba pinahiram ang sisiw sa angkan ng mallari???? that never made sense. JC Santos, ikaw ang nagdala ng buong pelikula.

SPOILERS AHEAD So, my boyfriend and I just watched Mallari yesterday and it didn't fail my high expectations. It deserves the hype. As usual, I'm going to be analyzing and rating the film.I think the story is great with parallels. The transitions between different timelines work really well and it's not confusing. Great choice of the cast too. Each of them has their own singularity. It is very well-written and the storyline is just superb. There were a lot of jumpscares in this movie but there are times that it wasn't necessary. Undoubtedly, Jonrey is the best Mallari. He sacrificed himself to end the curse with him – even if it means not having to see his kid. He did everything in his capabilities to protect his loved ones.With Fr. Severino, he didn't want to do it in the first place. You could see that he was having a moral dilemma between his beliefs and his love for his mother. I couldn't blame him, I'd honestly do it too. And Jonathan. Oh Jonathan, you selfish fuck. I understand that you mean well and you wanted the love of your life to be alive but fuck you for being selfish. You only think about yourself. You never learn. You brought the curse back to life to save your fiancée, but did you really save her? Or you just turned her into a monster that hates your guts? All you guys wanted was to have a family, and now it won't be possible because of your selfishness. One more thing, I don't get the hate about the sisiw part and manananggal part. I think it plays a crucial role in the film. It doesn't deserve the hate huhu. The ending could be better but in totality, I could say that this was one of the best Filipino movies I've seen.

i honestly do not know how to feel about this movie.my original motivation to watch this was purely for piolo but with every passing "plot twist", i was inching slowly into regret. severino mallari's story was simply too intriguing to resist but i predicted the messiness of compressing three generational piolos into a 2 hour film. the good aspects of this movie were accompanied by upsetting downsides (that my choosy watcher ahh decided for herself), therefore diluting its excellence into a neutral "mehh, interesting movie". nevertheless, i had still enjoyed certain scenes (especially when i found out elisse was playing a character of my namesake! sarap pakinggan ng name ko off piolos toungue <3 kahit na medj oa yung felicity na yun hmph) which made the watch worthwhile. however, im still utterly pissed at the jumpscares that only served as reminders that this was supposed to be a horror movie. lastly, thank you closeted lucas played by jc santos! ++ kudos to those incharge of the set though, i was admiring the beauty of those places throughout the entirety of the movie! wtf was that "pass the sisiw" thou, bleghhh

Admittedly, I am not a fan of horror films, especially when it clings on predictable jumpscares and poorly rendered gore for the shock factor, without focusing on the plot. Mallari's attempt to patch the stories of three generations together was honestly refreshing to see, but remains only an attempt, as it is not exempt from the clichés of Filipino horror films. Performances from Piolo Pascual and JC Santos held the film together for me, as they were able to successfully portray both the subtle and covert malevolence intertwined within their characters.

Nasasayangan ako na horror ang piniling treatment o genre ng direktor para sa kwentong ito. Ang daming interesanteng bagay sa pelikula pero nakaka-disappoint na nauuwi ito sa gasgas na jumpscare sa huli. Pwede naman mag-horror kung sana mas may lalim yung pagtalakay sa kasaysayan o etnograpiya ng faith o magic practices ng ating mga ninuno (ayoko sanang makipagkumpara pero kitang-kita ito sa Koryanong pelikula na Exhuma). 1 star para sa acting ni JC. 1 star para sa ambisyon ng pelikula kahit hindi matagumpay ang lahat ng binato ng kwento sa manonood. 0.5 star sa audacity nilang magpalabas ng sobrang gory na pelikula sa MMFF. DID NOT LIKE IT AT ALL!!! the concept of it being focused on the first serial killer in Philippines turned into a bunch movie tropes (horror, fiction, sci fi, and melodrama). The production is great but the acting isn't good. Jumpscares were underwhelming and cheap (Having big black eyes isn't scary). I was expecting a crime/thriller movie, which could've been good and way better rather than mixing it with fiction, gulat ako may aswang na nadamay tapos yung sisiw na lipat ng lipat ughh. Had the potential ganda na sana. Many scenes in the movie are anti climax, jumpscare that had nothing to do with the plot but still proceed to scare the character wahh scary.I cannot explain how I want just a simple crime/thriller movie that isn't mainstream or indie typa movie. Just a perfect crime based movie here in the Philippines with a better production and this was it but it took a big turn to be THAT.OVER ALL 2 STARS one for Papi P and one for Janella Salvador.

this reads like a play script I would've written back in grade 10—all the big ideas, without any real writing skills, polishing, nor attention to detail. but is somewhat redeemed by a surprisingly good performance from that one actor (jc santos)the writing is just bad; stiff dialogue, blatant exposition, and just seriously one-dimensional writing. not one ounce of subtlety nor barely any attention to detail which bleeds into the seemingly good production (e.g. that one scene where severino's victims tell jonathan to not do it? there were not 57 of them). and if you're going to fictionize a historical figure, TELL US! and either be historically accurate or not! this film consistently tip-toed around being historical and outright fiction. i would've been aight if they atleast atayed true to what was known and made up all the unknowns, making it a compelling telltale/actual telling of the story. but no the kid from the opening scene had to SOMEHOW remember exactly who killed her mother in the cover of night. that's just not how it happened. tl;drmallari (2023) doesn't even try. except jc santos, he tried.

When I heard that there would be a movie about a Filipino priest who was a serial killer, I was excited to watch it since real-life serial killer stories made me curious to the point I'll research about it on the internet. I have also watched Jeffrey Dahmer's series on Netflix so I was expecting that Mallari movie was something like that. I was a bit disappointed that the movie contains fictional characters and stories like the two Mallari generations and the time-traveling thing. It made me research what is real or not hahaha lol. The movie was more leaning on the aswang, kulam, curse type of Filipino horror story, more than focusing on Mallari's POV. However, the characters were great. Piolo Pascual did a great job in portraying different roles in different timelines. Other characters like Janella Salvador and JC Santos played their roles well.

Johnrey best boi!!!I feel the need to ask, sinong middle child kaya ang na-conceive matapos maglaba ng nanay niya noong umulan ng sama ng loob kaya nasalo lahat sa batya, tapos noong sinilang pinagdesisyunang itaas ang bandera ng mga middle child?—because this just goes to show to never underestimate the middle children. Or something along the lines. If we reach quite a bit further, the shoe will fit.I’m a strong believer that Mallari is also big on middle child propaganda. Chz. Johnrey just raised the bar, and he never got down from there. The ending, tying all the stakes to Jonathan’s choices, love, and mistakes, is probably the only end of the road that I will accept given that this film’s agenda was to take things up a notch from the current movie landscape that can be seen in our locality. Johnrey (being my favorite of the Mallari men, so let me once again shine a light on him) was there to create contrast, moral ambiguities, and drive the stakes into an extensive pitfall—and the pitfall was just that, balls-deep. Mallari, then, for all its worth and not just the ending, was an adventurous take of the Filipino supernatural lores, the historical figure that heralded the first serial killings sighted in the country, and the ambition to create a noir motion picture avant-garde among films in the industry that are still struggling to get away from the love teams and third-parties formula. Perhaps, the glaring criticism to be made is the shortcomings in execution that anchored what turned to be just potential by the end. A lot of efforts have gone into this and if we nitpick each of them, I am fairly certain that on their own, these individual efforts are granted high praises. In some aspects, however, when they are expected to work well together, they grapple with finding such a way to actually mesh in compatibility—but end up leaving one, two, or the other on a rather lackluster note, holding back what could have been a remarkable sequence. (There are choices that I disagree with, among them, sequences that translate to transphobia and hate crimes against prostitution—but to further name a few of these choices, this review would do well on that.)That is to say that, though I agree with the choice for wrapping up the primary character’s story, among (above-mentioned) other things, the progression of his character could have been subtly shown and fine tuned throughout the film. Alas, with such an extravagant narrative filled with complicated layers, the movie being too busy, the ending became abrupt. On the note of acknowledging Jonathan, his storyline couldn’t have happened without the intergenerational storyline connecting the characters that Piolo Pascual embodied. It is with such element, aided by time traveling and the use of vintage themes, that Mallari became what it is: an explored genre. In spite of my criticisms, it was still a hard work to have made a movie such as this one, and even harder still to execute interconnected storylines resulting to an impressionable film—of that, it was never a doubt.I do hope that directors and production crews alike take note of choices, as expounded in the story, and the film itself in its entirety, for future projects.

48The Philippines has all the culture, creativity, talent, and tech necessary to be rising film Mecca. And while I can applaud Mallari for really trying something really creative with a really interesting piece of Filipino history, much of this movie is really lazy and uninspiring. At times, this movie borderlines on the comedic muses of a Praybet Benjamin movie. The horror aspects are not scary at all, and the inter connectivity between generations is terribly written. The Philippines can do so much better, and I’m sure it has, but it’s got to find its next visionary to usher Pinoy film into a new/uncharted territory of greatness.But what do I know I’m just a Filipino-American kid from Arizona that put this on for my parents and just ended up watching this.

It's the type of film that "could've been better, but they chose a different path and stuck with it." Many scenes felt odd to me. The sound design was terrific, but the jump scares weren't very scary, to be honest. What I really loved about the film was JC Santos's top-tier acting. Despite its flaws, it's still a solid horror film with a great effort in delivering Mallari's story, though it could have been better executed.

I wanted to enjoy this, gusto ko talagang magustuhan but there were too much choices in this na super distracting to me. I went in to this with high expectation kasi it was so well received during Metro Manila Film Festival 2024 but I ended up just being disappointed and frustrated, bullshit ba yung mga reviews nun? They heavily marketed this as based on Juan Severino Mallari's life, but it's not really?!?!? It's pure fantasy. Ang dami nilang creative input/choices that it reminded me so much of when Eugene Domingo was making a "movie" about Josephine Bracken's life in Ang Babae Sa Septic Tank 3 (2019). A time travelling serial killer? Seryoso ba? Also did they really try to justify a serial killer's actions? Sa panahon ngayon I feel like that is something the storytellers need to be careful with, example yung Netflix's Dahmer series; it's so crazy to think na that had some "influence" on some people. Not even 15 minutes in sa movie may mga cheap jumpscares na, they heavily relied on it through out the movie too, it got boring really fast. There was even one jumpscare na I'm sure they ripped off from Smile (2022), I never watched it but it was on trailer. Mallari also does a lot of telling and not showing; information dumping is so lazy. Why do we need to know why this random old lady has a long life? And bakit kailangan natin malaman yung wife ni Johnrey Mallari is like a coconut na brown on the outside and white on the inside??? Like, So? ANO NAMAN?!? As a viewer, anong use ng information na to? The movie is 2 hours long and I felt every minute of it, ang daming unnecessary scenes. And the ghosts and monsters in this! Holy sh*t, it looked so bad. Using CGI was really a choice, their faces ended up looking so goofy. To think na this is something they could've easily done with makeup/practical effects, like aren't we known for that? Nakita na natin yung talent ng Filipinos dun with the Shake, Rattle and Roll movies through the years! Were the filmmakers so cheap and it's something na ayaw nilang gastusan? And the 21 year age difference between Janella Salvador and Piolo Pascual; the Philippine entertainment industry needs to stop doing this. Like, maybe Piolo doesn't look it but he's old enough to be her Dad. Na he has a son na just a year older lang kay Janella Salvador. Mallari (2023) is way too goofy for me to even notice if the actors are doing good, or if anything in it is. Nakakagigil lang yung movie.Apparently there's another Juan Severino Mallari project in the works, but this one is an international series and starring Dennis Trillo, and said to be more of a biopic. P.S. I paused halfway through this movie because I needed a break, it gave me a headache. I watched Running Man Philippines' latest episode and then Sunod; another MMFF 2019 movie entry because I feel like I needed a dose of a good Pinoy horror movie.P.P.S.That scene of the manananggal flying around the room, obviously panicking and then it cuts to some characters just staring at it, mixed with the goofy looking cgi. Seryoso ba talaga? I ended up laughing so much during that scene. Even replayed it because it was so goofy na it's funny, it was the only scene in the movie that got a reaction out of me.

Mallari (2023) was considered a historical thriller film but instead, we got a horror fantasy film that somehow got recognized by Warner Bros. One thing I must admit is that the film has great spectacular production sets & designs. And it's such a shame that it was implemented for this horror film with cheap jump scares and unnecessary time-traveling twist to make the premise so interesting. I wished the story should've been like GomBurZa. I actually do not know that this film is "loosely" based on Fr. Juan Severino Mallari, who is the first documented serial killer from the Philippines. I said "loosely based" because the film even adds two unnecessary fictional characters related to Mallari. The Mallari trio is played by none other than Piolo Pascual. It is very impressive for one actor to play three roles in this film, but his "present" Mallari performance was so unconvincing throughout the film, compared to his two roles. It would've been nice if Piolo just played the actual Mallari, not this make-believe storytelling.The story is complicated and it makes me wonder what are they trying to tell other than Mallari's actions for his killings. I can't get enough about this time-travelling twist. It creates a turmoil to its story that I can't describe and say anything positive about it.If Mallari take the GomBurZa approach as a proper historical thriller, it would've been a great film. But unfortunately, the film shall take its path for being a convoluting mess with great visuals and production design.

Came for Piolo, stayed for absolutely everyone but Piolo.First off, the writing for the climax scene was pretty good, with Janella Salvador, JC Santos, and Geraldine Villamil (Mariang Capac) doing a lot of the heavy lifting. Piolo Pascual, and overall the writing of the main character Jonathan, I think, is a main weak point of this movie for me. Piolo was not believable as a doctor or as a filmmaker (maybe a little bit as a serial killer), his character is weakly fleshed out outside of the obsession with some vague thing with the house and its connection to Janella, and the moustache and glasses are just laughable. I was honestly more captivated by Lucas and the other mga mambabarang.Overall, needed paring down -- some roles were superficial yet occupied too much screen time (cough the kids and I mean all the kids, and the policemen cough) -- should imo have focused on Severino Mallari more, and not used godawful CG for old Gloria Diaz.

i would have written my review way earlier had it not been for the jumble of mess this movie turned my thoughts into. well, at least it is loyal to that much.this movie was lacklustre at the very least, and mediocre at best. apart from its borderline misogynistic and transphobic elements, its ambition to sprinkle in a little bit of everything was quite disappointing in its delivery (especially the sci-fi bit). it came out rather messily. although history-centred films are rarely ever 100% accurate to their source material, adding in the astral projection bullshit just did not cut it for me. i think they should have just focused on fr. severino mallari alone; i think it would have done better as a psychological thriller. i felt more intensely from the jumpscares than the fight scenes, or even the supposedly emotional ones. in short, this movie did not work for me.

Honestly, in my opinion, the only good thing about this movie was Piolo's top-notch acting. While I understand that making horror movies is one of the hardest genres, it's not surprising when a Filipino horror movie turns out really bad. I wish it hadn't been this disappointing though. They clearly prioritized cinematography, but in a horror film, the horror aspect should never be overlooked. The pacing of some scenes and the editing were more painful to watch than the priest's killing scenes. On a positive note, I appreciated the fresh take on the famous story of the first serial killer. However, the storytelling was weak, and some elements didn't make complete sense, seemingly just to fulfill the director's vision.

If I were to give this film an honest rating, I'd say it's a 2.2 out of 5. Why the .2? Gawa nung "Amoy kiffy!" EME. Pero I can say that they tried the best they could for this movie naman. Okay 'yung actors, lalo na si Piolo at JC. Mahirap gumanap ng apat sa iisang movie. Tapos kay JC, very galing talaga mag act, very natural. The storyline for me is OK. I can see why they didn't stick with just retelling the past. Maybe because of lacking history documents? So, I get it naman. For the missing points naman, siguro I was bummed out with the dialogues? The actors were not the problem, it was the corny ass script. There were times the scenes were just unnatural and forced. Tapos 'yung camera works, ok ok siya but may scenes na pwede baguhin 'yung angles. And then the CGI. I mean, improving? Siguro if I wasn't paying attention with the whole movie and just paying attention to Piolo, siguro hindi ko mapapansin eh. Pero may times na it's giving laughable instead of spooky. Overall, I enjoyed the movie.

It’s been a while that i’ve seen a decent Filipino horror movie and I would say this one doesn’t disappoint. A pretty good storytelling and a very nice acting by Papa P ( i refused to call him any name otherwise, my aunts will be so proud)SFX aint that good but not bad either. Also, the song by the end are a pretty banger. The only thing is that if you’re not filipino and watched this, high chance you’ll be confused about the malignos and stuff. The folklore wasn’t explained enough and some people might not get the correlation between the supernatural beings and the chick being passed on to another person. It’s one of those movies where you have to search them by the end of watching it just to gets the supernatural beings much better but it doesn’t really affect the plot that much. Still a good watch and actually kept my attention from start to the end.

"Mallari" was intriguing, bold and underwhelming.Seemingly a partly fictional, partly real life inspired account on the Philippines' first documented serial killer, Severino Mallari (keep in mind when! :O). I thought there's some cool stuff in the concept/ideas department, throughout. Really liked the structure too.Well, Piolo Pascual was pretty good with his various (quite well distinguished) roles. Several other neat contributions from the cast, particularly from JC Santos.I thought the movie went a bit over its head, to be honest. Both plot and execution-wise. On a more "focused" perspective, the plot has a few glaring plotholes and some underwhelming execution (particularly where action and horror are involved, for the most part).Several different approaches: some better, some worse (personally, I didn't enjoy some of the jumpscare technique with the editing). Two bigger scenes... one head-on, another avoided.The plot/story, while well structured and definitely intriguing, on a closer look, should feel quite shallow in a few regards.The latter stages were reasonable, particularly again structure-wise.I didn't particularly enjoy the ending, though it should be ok-ish (if you enjoy the "reason"; I didn't and I missed some wickedness, for sure).Overall, an ambitious and interesting movie that I felt went for more than it could manage, though it's certainly understandable that you should go for it ^_^ I felt the plot could've been stronger, particularly around the "origin/reason" and the execution could also have been better. The horror elements felt lacking, particularly in several (avoided) scenes. But I think they did pretty great in creating something quite interesting around the "main story" element. I think this can totally be a 6 too but I'll fall back to the reasonable 5 for this one.

One of the best Filipino horror movies I’ve seen, Mallari is full of suspense and horror. Piolo Pascual is outstanding in his role portraying three different characters. The story begins with a man named Jonathan who returns to his hometown, uncovering a sinister ancestral curse that has plagued his family for generations. The setting has haunting visuals and an unsettling score.The flashback and present scenes tie in well with the storyline, and it’s definitely a great watch.[From trailer:]“Since I was a child, I knew something was different about my family. I hope that one day I will uncover the Mallari family secret.”

Mallari tackles the intersectionality of religion, faith, folklore, culture, history, and science. Spanning three different timelines, I think it was presented pretty seamlessly, though it could have been executed better. I think this performance if Piolo Pascual is a bit lukewarm. Despite their short appearances in the film, JC Santos and Janella Salvador had great performances here.For the most part, it was a bit sad that the film leaned more into the cheap jump scare horror when it could have capitalized on the opportunities brought about by religion and humanity. However, it would take a certain awareness and attention to detail to realize that there is a deeper horror embedded in the film - that love is a curse, and the lengths that a person will go through for the person they love, regardless of the consequences they face in return.

a horror film that only relies on jumpscares and gore to scare you isn't really a good horror film, no?i had high expectations for this and they were just not met. the plot was all over the place, the dialogue trying to sound deep even when they were in the present time, the distracting CGI, the time traveling. i can go on but i think the main issue was the film failed to just focus on one thing and flesh out the story from there. the main plot about a priest who's a serial killer is interesting enough but they just had to add a bunch of other elements that resulted to a convoluted story. it's frustrating to think about what could have been.

Mallari was the movie I was most looking forward to out of all the MMFF entries last year, given it was the first movie distributed by Warner Bros (I could be wrong here), but sad to say it's at most a solid 3/5.While it tackles a lot of firsts, it's also a movie that uses the redundancy of the Filipino "timpla". Like, men are so stupid and unreasonable. Jonathan, darling, I get it—it's Janella Salvador, but really? Father, why is the wig weave showing like that? (Tatak Pinoy films to have bad wigs, I said what I said). JC Santos, that nose acting, bro. I'm so frigging tired. I don't even watch horror, but those jumpscares did nothing to me—they are just jumpscares and didn't add anything to the plot.I think in this day and age, we would all rather die than be a maligno. I also would like to point out that he became a werewolf at some point, and the cinematography used shadows—and the shadows were cheap in form. I guess I want to say in the end, Filipino films' bare minimum is moving in the right direction.

A man goes back in timeto figure out the mystery of a serial killernamed Mallari.Halos lahat ng pwede mong makita sa isang horror thriller film ay inilagay nila rito. Nakakatuwa dahil kaya pala natin makaisip ng ganitong konsepto na siksik sa iba’t ibang elemento.Hindi lang siya basta patayan, habulan, sigawan. Maraming pasabog sa kwento na tila walang hangganan. Sunod sunod ang mga plottwists sa dulo at wala itong hingahan.Piolo Pascual gave his usual good acting. You can see the distinction among the three characters he is portraying. Gloria Diaz was graceful. Geraldine Villamil was terrifying. The performance of JC Santos was impressive and applaudable, serving as one of the film’s highlights.The color grading, scoring, sound design, and cinematography altogether gave a thrilling atmosphere. The movie’s original song, composed by Quest and interpreted by juan karlos, is a powerful appropriate soundtrack.Mallari’s greatest strength still lies on its concept. The effort to be a different kind of horror film was seen and appreciated. If watching  means getting better horror stories, then count us in.Let  be the start of something new.READ FULL MOVIE REVIEW HERE:www.goldwinreviews.com/post/mallari

Hilarious... Uncomfortable... And one unique hell of a ride!Mallari, though not perfect, still offers an enjoyable horror flick that has FILIPINO smeared all over it, be it 1800s, 1940s, and the modern times... and even has the legendary monsters we all grew up hearing about... but of course with a unique twisted flavor! Piolo Pascual devoured not once but thrice with his triple role! The twist was a lil predictable but executed just fine making this whole experience satisfying enough for me! Also plus points for the #kapampangan represent! Janella Salvador did such a serve too!Do note that despite this being based off a serial killer, it is highly fictionalized, so if you're expecting a biopic, you'll surely be disappointed!I'm glad to see that ph cinema is alive and well! it was packed

An entertainingly insane, if at times, clunky murder thriller that is more compelling with the crazy plot threads and character motivations and choices, and far less so with incredibly cheap scares and a mix of beautiful cinematography and design and underwhelming visual effects.Performances are strong all around, esp Piolo Pascual being able to somehow have a incredible range playing three versions of himself. One scene with him in a church talking to demons is more compelling and scary then the litany of pointless jumpscares that didn't add much at all.
Writing is all over the place but Piolo's performance held the movie together. It's also fun to watch in a jampacked cinema.

Gusto ko lang sabihin na hindi ikinahiya ng film na ito ang transphobia & criminalization ng sex work - baka kasi kailangan lang din masabi sakaling may nakikinig, so yeahhh…nakalulungkot.Anyways, the concept could have been a top tier religious horror/suspense/slasher/thriller (heck even camp) but it was horror only during the sigawan moments. After that nothing was sustained. I left the theater na walang baon pauwi. I learned nothing new abt Fr. Severino Mallari, what was his real motive labas sa fiction…or idk  which was real and documented (ang ganda sana i-explore). Di ko rin maiwasan ikumpara sa Seklusyon ni Erik Matti which was for me, an eye opener to the horrors of the Catholic church. That film perfectly blended horror + criticism on the Catholic church. I remember leaving the cinema with lots of questions on Catholicism. Dito wala, purely entertainment. Pero yun nga, gets ko kasi ito ay MMFF at hindi Cinemalaya (pero MMFF din naman yung Seklusyon kaya lang that was a different time I guessss huehue).So sana ibang direction naman ang tahakin ng Severino ni Dennis Trillo (looking forward to that).PSLove the gays beside us screaming “Go Valentina!” MMFF 2023, SM Lipa

Let’s get the good things out of the way: Piolo Pascual is terrific portraying multiple characters, each of his character given just enough time to be fleshed out in a 2-hour runtime. The production is gorgeous, a really big step up here for Filipino cinema.I admire the concept of this film, has so much potential to showcase a unique Filipino horror experience with a touch of history and historical fiction. The history side of things was handled pretty decently, but unfortunately the horror itself is the singular thing holding this film back, relying on the usual cheap jumpscare tactics, with lackluster use of its unique atmosphere to build up dread and tension.This film could’ve been so much more than what we have, but at the very least I’ll give it this: it is a step-up from the generic Filipino horror rubbish that we get every year.6.5/10

sobrang needy and clingy nung sisiw parang ako lang emei wish it didn't resort to cheap jumpscares too often just to fill the run time because it's the last thing it needed. the dread, creepy atmosphere is already there that cabrido has crafted the backdrop of these three characters quite nicely. the film had A LOT of creative freedom and shied away from being historically accurate and became a non-linear multiverse folk horror that might've been easily given me the ick, but i still appreciated how it became its own thing as it progresses, which leads as to why i still think it worked for me; it is committed on what it wanted to be and its theme of greed for power is clearly understood. piolo proved his acting prowess once again playing three generations of mallari, a tour de force performance.Metro Manila Film Festival 2023

Initially gave this four stars after leaving the theater, but after giving it some thought I’m taking it down to 3.5 Mallari (2023) boasts impeccable set design and costumes that make each time period feel robust yet still feel lived in. Pascual and Santos’ performances carry a lot of the weight of this film for me with Pascual delivering in all three roles and Santos’ grit as Lucas. Janella Salvador’s Agnes also packed a punch despite her somewhat short screen time. Apart from Pascual’s portrayal of each Mallari, the film’s choice of anchoring each era to the conflicts that affected the Filipino of its period. The feudal tensions of the 1800s and the CIA Aswang psy-op gave more body to the time periods presented. The burden each Mallari carried through time eventually made that ending make sense to me. Greed, on both systemic and intimate levels, drive the motivations of each character. Considering all of this, what made Mallari (2023) fall flat for me was its horror aspect. I am no expert on the horror genre and seeing this film made me want to read up on it haha lol but I found that the jumpscares eventually felt cheap, predictable, and unnecessary. The CGI also faltered during one scene with Doña Facunda, though it warrants a pwede na from me kasi di naman siya ganun ka-distracting. So ayun! Also the girl who played Felicity looks like she knows what an iPhone is so medyo di bagay sa time period. Anyways, fun movie! Folk catholicism in Filipino horror is always so interesting.

A smorgasbord of horror genres that worked well!Watching Mallari is an journey and the ride paid off really well. The film had such an interesting oremise and promise that accounted for a fictional spin on a historical event that shaped the town of Magalang, Pampanga.Pao Orendain's lenses played such a big role in making sure every beat was felt and audiences were immersed. From the colos and light8ng used up to the choreography of the camerawork, it was a feast fornthe eyes. The overall production design was superb as well. Having three eras worth of costumes, props, sets is a hard task but it was executed really well. Everything felt too realistic and you can't deny the time out into crafting each set.But of course, the acting performances of the cast are the highlight. Piolo Pascual delivered such a great take on three distinct personalities from three different time periods. From the murderous priest, steadfast documentarian, up to the persistent doctor, all Piolos had their own personalities and nuances. Best actor calibre performance.JC Santos and Gloria Diaz also shone in their roles by delivering really strong and powerful performances. As usual, JC Santos was amazing and undoubtedly a strong contender for Best Actor with this performance. Meanwhile, Gloria Diaz was eerie, creepy, and committed. Last time I saw a strong Gloria Diaz performance like this was way back in "Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo" & its sequel and "Nasaan Ka Man."Special shoutout to Paps Raffy Tejada! Again, giving life to roles he's portraying. He's a breath of fresh air amidst the eerie fele8ng this film gave off. Kuddos.Kuddos to Direk Derick Cabrido for successfully mounting such a great film. It's one of the best Filipino horror films in modern times!

Aside from being an intense and original folk horror, MALLARI is a provocative portrayal of how greed, obsession of power, and complacency allow evil to thrive. Religion, imperialists, and landlords… they create monsters. Piolo Pascual gives the performance of his career, and JC Santos proves once again that he is a one of a kind talent. There are times when the script’s expository dialogue makes the film cringey, but Mallari is still a powerful, thoughtprovoking film.

The story is a filmmaker's dream, inspired by the events of Fr. Severino Mallari's killings, it's a complex and expansive story, going back & forth through 3 centuries worth of lore. It's also an opportunity for some gorgeous production, showcasing 19th & 20th century dialect, environment, and aesthetic, which this film brilliantly executed. The storytelling itself left something to be desired, where more proper character exploration were more than welcome. The killings as well is something that is promised but weren't fully delivered.It's worst aspects are it's delivery of horror, its plot twist, and ending. It has the worst standards of Philippine horror filmmaking, or rather, the standard is the worst, relying solely on loud sounds and jumpscares. They could've saved it with the make-up & design, but it's not enough. The plot twist can be seen a mile away, being able to call it out by a single scene. And lastly, without a doubt it's worst liability, is it's ending. It tries to be smart, aiming for shock value, but instead comes across as self-indulgent, and downright idiotic. It's a classic horror trope that thinks it's clever, but rather dumb.The concept and ambition is worth checking it out, but it really just can't shy away from the worst tendencies and shortcomings of Philippine horror clichés, which is a real shame as it has everything going for it to be a trailbrazer & change mainstream Philippine cinema for the better, but i guess for now, this will do, and i hope it's enough to spark more films like these.

the first act was messy af, thank god the succeeding acts managed to hold up...the movie didn't have to rely much on jumpscares. the story of fr. mallari in itself was already chilling enough. that was enough for the "scary parts" to revolve around it.trust me, the parts with real live humans were way scarier. *that* chasing scene was even scarier. the jumpscares already drained the viewer's energy to the point that they can no longer react well to the parts that actually mattered.overall, though, i liked the folk horror film this story became. for a more historically accurate take on this i'll wait for the tv series.AV-wise, everything is perfect. i've become a fan of piolo and jc santos now.

A very ambitious attempt in holding a story of three generations of the Mallari clan, adding Filipino folklore as part of its speculative writing, Mallari struggles to land smoothly. It’s a mystery/psychological thriller/folklore tale mashed into historical account of the very first Filipino serial killer.Almost all tropes from recent horror films, such as the Insidious, The Conjuring, and even The Nun series of films, appear in this film. Filipino filmography-wise, it has a touch of Nocebo and Ang Mga Kaibigan Ni Mama Susan.Despite it being so convoluted, the film managed to deliver a horror film that showcases the talents of its ensemble—Piola Pascual cementing himself as one of the actors in the industry to not underestimate.Personally, these kinds of stories are my jam. And yes gwapo si Papa P.

The plot of this film was promising, they could've focused only on the astral projection ability of the Mallari clan and build something on that alone but what happened was, they stuffed so much subplots to cut the loose ends. As the film progressed, the aswang element was added, then the caretaker element, then the curse (sisiw) inheritance, and so on. It became less interesting to me because of those subplots. I was expecting it to be a psychological horror like The Shining but the subplots kind of ruined it. Still, this film offers something new and leaves a lot of room for discussion, there is so much to unpack. Again, I really think the subplots were employed to remove the plot holes and I think they are successful in accomplishing that objective but at the expense of a better storyline.

"Walang Diyos Sa Gabi"Mallari is a horror flick that is surprisingly good. There are elements that you would not expected to be added in this film. It has shockingly many twists and turns in this movie. If you thought this is a typical slasher/ serial killer movie, then think again. The cons of the movie is many annoying and unnecessary jumpscares. The beginning is also confusing and some characters are cringe to watch but the middle point of the movie will definitely recover what they did to the beginning. Also, the cinematography and performances of main characters is surprisingly good and it is worth to watch. Masasabi ko lang na may pag asa pa ang pelikulang Filipino pagdating sa horror. Dapat tayo wag mawawalan ng pag asa at least we are improving and learning from the mistakes. P.S. There is a point somewhere in the fuzzy third act of Mallari where a character named Agnes confronts one of the Piolos [there are four] in this movie, where she tells him: “I knew you before as a doctor. Now you’re telling me you’re a fortuneteller.” I felt her confusion so hard. Because this movie is exactly like that: it does not know what it wants to be.Because what is this? A movie about a historical serial killer? A movie about a crusading documentarian during the American colonial period? A movie about a lovelorn doctor? A movie about aswangs or manananggals? A movie about American military propaganda against the Huks? A movie about rural beliefs? A movie about social justice? A movie about the servant class eating the rich [or at least the sinful]? A movie about proto-TikTokers? [See Felicity’s final filmed confession.]A movie about ... time travel?When the time travel element was introduced, that was when I finally decided to just suspend all my longing for this movie to make sense, and just surrender to the horrendous absurdity of it all.Fact was, I was so ready to do that already the first instant Mallari wanted to underline its horror elements [mostly through cheap jump scares] by announcing them with screeching music that bludgeons the viewer to pay attention and be scared. [Screeching music. A ghost!] But it doesn’t help that they mostly announce ghouls who just stand there — and do absolutely nothing of consequence. The movie does this ad infinitum that by the time we reach the 999th jump scare, you’re just ... numb with boredom.Which is sad, because the story of Fr. Severino Mallari — the 18th century Filipino priest who is marked in our history as the country’s first recorded serial killer — is already so rich with narrative possibilities. Just following that story, even if the filmmakers have to embellish it to make up for the lack of concrete historical data, would have sufficed. But screenwriter Enrico Santos, perhaps fearful that he didn't have enough material to constitute a screenplay, opted to fictionalize by making this a story about a curse transcending generations, threading it all with the very hoary device of ... time travel. That’s what you call a choice.A lot of the narrative elements of the film was certainly a CHOICE: killing off Mylene Dizon in the first few moments was a choice [hello, Drew Barrymore in Scream!], and then bringing in her cowering boy to the last few minutes to round off this story with an arrest was a choice; a priest spouting off “woke knowingness” and then the film proceeding to demonstrate the “kill the gays” trope was a choice; having exactly three paintings of distant ancestors hanging in an old house as shorthand for character introductions was a choice [the other ancestors don’t matter to this family?]; Elisse Joson’s acting as a bitchy Felicity was a choice; the predictability of JC Santos’ character arc from the moment he encounters Didi was a choice; the lack of serial killing was a choice; the humanizing of the serial killer was a choice; demonizing St. Bartholomew [and then making a post-script to deny this] was a choice; Piolo’s bad wig and fake beard were a choice; having characters do mouthful expository dumps as dialogue at crucial moments of high drama [to explain away gnarly narratives] was a choice — but that one with Gloria Diaz explaining the existence of a time-traveling descendant with a knife to her throat was icing on the cake; the fact that there’s only one kind of moon — a full moon always bathed in red — was a choice.I was so excited to watch this film, and purposefully made it the first MMFF entry I would watch for 2023. I left the theater wondering what could have been if the screenplay was better. Sayang.

Oh God! That is a torture. An insufferably patchwork of clichés from the different genre canon that should combine to form a distinctive “something,” but only ends up feeling like a fanfic writer trying to ape what he believes to be art. It’s all terribly vapid, fake, manufactured, devoid of any true artistic sincerity and only trying to create the image of an artistic jack of all trades. Such an absolute disappointment considering what it can achieve.

“Ang isang tao ay kabuuan ng kanyang mga desisyon… minamahal… at mga pagkakamali.” (A person is made up of all of his decisions, beloveds, and mistakes.)i am usually hard to please when it comes to horror but Mallari was a pleasant surprise. the plot, particularly, piqued my interest: an origin story inspired by the very first documented Filipino serial killer, who happened to be a small town parish priest.Cabrido could easily make this a docu-style retelling but no. he took the material up a notch, made it an intergenerational story of the Mallaris, time-travelling in vignette storytelling, to unlock and reconcile each other’s past. honestly, that’s inextricably hard to land and i applaud the film just for this alone. the picturesque cinematography is just cherry on top. the vfx choices aren’t its strong suit. sometimes, i also question the relevance of its rather abundant jumpscares. that’s forgivable, at least for the most part. but you can’t dismiss how fresh this film was; how it was able to build such a unique tension with the audience made it bridge all of the mentioned shortfalls. overall, this film is a bloodcurdling picture of love—a curse in itself—as to what lengths it would take to love someone, even if we’ve become the monster ourselves. would you still call it love… or a curse spellbound?[Metro Manila Film Festival 2023]

Isn’t loving someone also a curse? If they did the usual and conventional type of biopic, it would have been a lot better tho. Nonetheless, I like this film to an extent, so much potential. I just hoped they explored the psychological and emotional turmoil Fr. Mallari has gone through as well as how he was persecuted and convicted. It would have been nice to see Mallari’s point of view and constant agonize and suffering going through his thoughts and with the people around him. Honest take is: real life stories are much scarier than the typical jump scares. I also don’t feel the astral projection and time travel thingy and not to mention, the sudden manananggal and werewolf scene we all didn’t see coming. However, we could not just deny the fact that Piolo and John Carlo did carry the film all throughout. They were spectacular and eerie. The real story is in itself something that would keep us at night. Focusing on the series of sudden murders in 1810 as well as the human leeches of his life would help us retrospect better the unfortunate era. After all, Mabuhay ang Pelikulang Pilipino. Kudos to Team Mallari.

Ang ganda ng konsepto ng pelikulang 'to.At first naguguluhan ako kung saan ito papunta but once the threads started to make sense talagang nabibilib ako how well-crafted the mystery surrounded this movie.For a Filipino horror movie, napaka-husay ng production design at cinematography nito. Makikita mo mismo ang kaibahan ng tatlong timeline dahil dito.Piolo Pascual delivers distinctive performances, consistently adapting to the story's different timelines. From an innocent to killer gaze, talagang matutunaw ka kay Papa P.The film's strength was showcased in the third act of the movie. Serving the final conclusion in each needles they've build up at the start of the movie. Maaaring minsan bumabagal ito at tila nawawala sa momentum ngunit naibabalik nila ito kada nasasagot ang mga itina-taas nitong mga tanong.What I don't like about Filipino movies is they always tend to hold back with the ending---luckily, Mallari doesn't!Alam ng Mallari ang storyang gusto nitong italakay at tuloy-tuloy nila itong inilatag. The movie never lose their focus and I really enjoyed it despite the cliche jumpscares and some bad scene choices.
didn't expect this film to be THIS good. hands down to all ze people who made this film. kudos!

Gorgeous production on this, but this movie is pretty dumb. It's hard to talk about without giving too much away, but we can start with the horror aspects of this, which largely involve jump scares that don't actually lead to anything. Like, I guess the ghosts are just there to play pranks on the characters, like they were TikTok influencers.But here's an example of something dumb: at one point, the main character is handed a film reel that he's been looking for by a girl who apparently just had an encounter with the ghost. To be clear: this is a film reel that holds vital information regarding the very reason he's gone back to his family home in the first place, potentially giving him the answers he's been looking for in order to prevent some future disaster.In the next cut, we see him sweeping in the garden. Guess it wasn't that important after all.Full review on Spot.ph

The province of Pampanga is famed for its many “firsts” in the country, especially in the field of religion. Unfortunately, this includes the first ever documented serial killer, Padre Juan Severino Mallari of Macabebe. When I learned about him several years ago, I never would have thought that his story would be adapted to a film (and soon, into a mini series, as well). His tragic story already made it to the national television a few times. But to the…

Convoluted and highly derivative. It seems like whoever developed the story for Mallari was inspired by too many TV shows and movies available on Netflix (Dark, the Fear Street series, Inception, and the Insidious franchise, just to name a few) and decided to create a film that captures the best elements from each, just packaged in a different manner. Unfortunately, what they ended up with is a film facing a serious identity crisis. It desperately wants to tell so many stories but fails to dive deeply into most of them. I left the cinema feeling disappointed because I was really looking forward to watching this.Top-notch acting from Piolo Pascual and JC Santos, though.

Mallari takes place in the nineteenth century in Magalang, Pampanga. Following the crimes of Father Severino Mallari, back in the day, he used to serve the church and champion the needs of his poor countrymen. He was known as a priest who had a heart for the needy. Everything was fine until an unfortunate event took place: his mother got ill.Mallari is a film beautifully created, packed with scenes that will keep you on the edge of your seat. It was both visually and audibly beautiful.The actors were outstanding in terms of portraying their characters. JC Santos was remarkable in this flick. Piolo Pascual made another outstanding performance that will surely entertain you and make you love him more as an actor. Elise Joson was equally commendable for her short yet very effective portrayal. Janella Salvador spiced up the movie's last act with some flavor and intensity. Enrico Santos and Derick Cabrido's screenplay and direction were a match made in heaven. The cinematography, color grading, production design, and sound design were all remarkable.If you are looking for an entertaining and outstanding horror film, Mallari is definitely for you.

Mallari (Derick Cabrido, '23)MMFF4.5 / 5 stars"There is no God at night,"I was very excited when I heard the news about this movie, considering that it was distributed by Warner Bros. PH. It's just refreshing to see Piolo Pascual on the big screen again (He's also in GomBurZa movie, by the way). It was a messy puzzle piece in the beginning. I'm not that impressed with the opening sequence since I expected a little more brutal, but the middle gets a little more interesting, and the third act is the kick and punch that I've been waiting for. Though the movie had jumpscares that felt tired, the production design, the sound design, and the cinematography is just AMAZING!! Piolo and JC Santos really delivered. The premise is really interesting as this is the only recorded serial killer priest in the Philippines. The elements added to it were very interesting but kind of failed to really play with it l, but all in all, I can say that I'm still proud of the output. Give Piolo Pascual the Best Actor!!!

i watched this today in person and i can tell you it was worth it! i don't usually watch horror films before but now i enjoy the genre so i tried this out for a change and it didn't disappoint me. the only documented serial killer in the Philippines is Juan Severino Mallari from Magalang, Pampanga. i am also kapampangan and i liked how they atleast tried to showcase our culture even in just glimpse like they tried to speak our language as the scenes were re-enacted and set in pampanga.the movie isn't perfect but it was really good and i could see the effort all throughout the film. what a beautiful production! some scenes may be a bit questionable BUT i liked how it also involved the humor of today's society, the way the culture of the past was portrayed like it was a re-enactment of past events in our history, and most importantly the filipino myths. god! i appreciate that it wasn't a slowburn also, it was just like getting hit by an axe on the head immediately. i am OBSESSED with this film, i just want to say what an entry!(p.s we are not a clan of killers as a quote from the film) except the mallaris.

Was never a fan of horror/thriller films kasi mabilis talaga ako matakot at mapraning but ever since nalaman ko yung story ni Fr. Mallari at nung may rumor na gagawin siyang pelikula hindi na ako nagdalawang isip na ito ang unahin kong panoorin mag-isa. Afterall, im a sucker for history talaga at istorya ito first documented serial killer priest sa Pilipinas. Ang ganda na napakita nila ang tatlong magkaibang time period sa pilipinas at mas lalo ko pa ito nagustuhan kung paano nila ito tinahi at na overlap dahil sa ***tooot***. Huling-huli nila ang atensyon ko rito kudos! Epektibo ang mga jumpscares, may iba rito na ramdam mo na agad pero meron rin na di mo akalain na may gugulat. May mga cliche scenarios na sa tingin ko naman ay hindi mawawala sa isang thriller film pero sa tingin ko naman ay naging smooth pa rin naman ang panonood ng pelikula. Medyo disappointed nga lang ako sa ibang dialogues na sa tingin ko ay mas better na i-reword o isulat. Masaya na nalahad sa pelikula na ito ang iba’t-ibang issue at kultura sa Pilipinas. Nandito ang ibang topic katulad ng classism, imperialism, greediness. Isama na rin natin na napakita rito ang iba’t-ibang myths at folklore na kinalakihan natin. Kudos sa editing. Grabe ang linis at ang ganda ng mga cuts ng bawat seq. Ang ganda ng mga biglaang cuts at transitions na nakadagdag ng pagkagulat sa mga manonood. Isa pang hinahangan ko ay ang production design. Wala ako masabi dahil ginawa nila ito from scratch. Taas talaga ng respeto ko sa kanila And to Piolo, GRABE KA TALAGA. Sobrang galing niya rito at hindi na ako mabibigla kung ibigay sakanya ang Best Actor Award. Napakadaming karakter ang kanyang ginampanan sa pelikula na ito at SLAAAAY si phiepasaur sa lahat. Pinakapaborito ko sigurong karakter niya ay si Fr. Severino. Tangina. Tangina lang. Kitang-kita mo yung pagiging banal at pagiging creepy niya at the same time. May isang scene talaga ako roon na pinakapaborito ko at di ko malilimutan. Lumabas nang sobra ang galing ni Piolo sa aktingan. Kitang-kita mo ang pagiging takot, pagkalito, at pagiging desperado niya. Grabe galing. Kay JC rin! Grabe sanay ako makita siya sa mga cliche romance films pero masaya ako na ibang character ang na portray niya rito. Bagay sakanya ang mga ganitong genre at character!Overall na enjoy ko ang pelikula, i just wished na sana mas nag focus ito sa lumang panahon pero gets ko naman na kailangan ng spice para mas maging kakaiba. Congrats sa Team Mallari! Also, shet sexy ng warner bros sa opening! Dazzerb naman ang hype and recognition ng film na ito.

These jumpscares are really lazy filmmaking to me. They're all so predictable, which is what makes Mallari, an otherwise decently constructed and handsomely produced film, a disappointment. There's little to no attempt to mislead or create an eerie atmosphere through score; sometimes, maybe being too loud isn't always the best choice for a scene. Also prolly why a lot of people didn't find it scary. Janella also a little awkward as Piolo's girlfriend. Some wonky vfx. Other than that, I like the rest, even Miss Gloria Diaz. Intriguing story held together by good editing choices and a committed central performance.

A promising concept centered on the Philippines' first serial killer who is a priest, but ultimately wasted by filling it with multiple ideas. The movie spans tropes from thriller, sci-fi, folklore, historical, romance, even family drama genres. Many interesting threads woven together, sure, but the design of this script could have been less busy so we could appreciate each one – personally, I would have liked more of a story behind the dark magic stuff so that it would be less of a twist in the final act and more of a creepy world long hidden in the shadows. Also, since the main character is a priest, a peek into the social climate of the church-centered 1800s provincial barrio would have been interesting (though I guess we already have Gomburza in the MMFF lineup to show us something like it). This is a horror movie with high-quality visuals, so you'd think the scares should at least be good. But no, they're all cheap jumpscares carried by a loud score or sound. I will admit that being in a packed theater contributes to a better viewing experience. People were really into it, screaming at the right parts, laughing at the right parts, anticipating with bated breath the (sometimes predictable plot twists) at the right parts. Mostly, it's thanks to a solid cast led by Piolo Pascual as three different characters and his friend Lucas played by JC Santos. Technically, aside from a particularly bad CGI scene, this is a decent feat for the Philippine horror genre. If only it were more focused.Full review here.

And yes, that one scene with a full-on CGI took me out for a bit.Still, this is crazy. Enjoyment of it depends on your willingness to accept whatever it throws on you. Astral projection, time travel, manananggal — they are all present here and it is admirable how the film balances all of these elements, jumping from one concept to another with ease. It helps that at the center of it is Piolo Pascual delivering his most exciting performance in years, and leading a solid cast.

+ Though being a Filipino horror-flick filled with cheap unearned jumpscares, the inspiration of classical Manananggal folklore, and having Philippines' first and only recorded serial killer as it's backbone, "Mallari" attempts to create a mythology around Fr. Mallari and their cursed bloodline, and succeeds only because it's clear that Warner Bros. really poured money into this. Plus points on it's creativity and ambition but its faults of overstaying it's welcome is prevelent. The messy pacing, editing, and story makes for a complicated albeit entertaining watch —carried by Piolo Pascual. Maybe Fr. Mallari's silhouette is enough to make this a memorable, maybe somewhat Hollywood 90s campy, horror film but, really, to hope for that is foolish. Still, I'll consider this a step in the right direction towards a future of more and more creative, challenging, and entertaining stories. Welcome to the Philippine entertainment industry Warner Bros.

Satisfying to see how it all came together but i feel like the film was too full circle that some parts were just predictable.I loved how mallari explored Filipino folklore because istg mfs be sleepin on that shit. The sci-fi twist was definitely interesting and I can’t say that I hated it. Honestly it kept me even more interested because I wanted to see how piolo pascual’s acting would survive in a sci-fi setting lawlz.Moral of the story: Ang pagibig nga naman… But also I love how the ending kinda explored something I think about at the end of the horror movies when the survivor walks off before the credits roll. Coz it’s like ok you survive but what quality of life are u rlly walking into? And when the girl said in the end that he should’ve just let her die, I was like damn fax that’s what I’m saying!
piolo pascual was incredible here, i think i now get his appeal to all the titas and lolas out there. wish we’ve gotten a more focused material revolving around the story of father mallari.

Mallari excels as a mystery/thriller, skillfully interweaving Fr. Severino Mallari's story with Filipino mythology, delving into themes of love, sacrifice, and the supernatural. For those seeking heart-pounding horror and intense scares, this might not cater to your expectations. Piolo Pascual's outstanding portrayal of three distinct characters remains a highlight, although some supporting actors struggle to match his depth, impacting the film's overall cohesiveness. Additionally, attempts at modern dialogue occasionally feel forced, aiming to resonate with contemporary audiences but often missing the mark.However, it falls short in certain technical aspects, with some special effects momentarily disrupting the immersion. Moreover, the excessive use of predictable jump scares might disappoint those seeking a more nuanced and suspenseful thriller experience. While the narrative's non-linear structure converges effectively, some scenes in the first act might feel eye-roll-worthy. Despite these initial hiccups, Mallari gains momentum over time. The clever interweaving of timelines culminates in a gripping third act, redeeming the movie's earlier flaws. Noteworthy performances, including JC Santos's compelling contribution, complement the film's exploration of mythology and folklore.Ultimately, Mallari remains a captivating watch for enthusiasts of intricate storytelling, showcasing Pascual's remarkable acting abilities. As it navigates through love, sacrifice, and the supernatural, Mallari's imperfect yet engaging portrayal leaves an indelible mark, resonating with those fascinated by the depths of human experience and the enigmatic allure of Filipino folklore.Peak Filipino cinema is back on the menu.

Mallari, the 3rd film I’ve seen this MMFF 2023.. Maybe I was expecting it to be good but it left me pretty disappointed.Pros: Sound design was pretty effective. I think JC Santos and Piolo Pascual’s acting was effective.Cons: Convoluted story made it hard to understand. I like non-linear storytelling, but in this case, It wasn’t executed properly. The dialogues were cringey. Aside from JC and Piolo, the supporting cast didn’t help in elevating the movie. I don’t know if its bad writing or the actors didn’t give the script justice. The insertion of humor is unnecessary and didn’t add anything to the table. I wish that they have stick to a specific storyline of the 1st Pinoy serial killer instead of adding storylines involving Filipino mythology and creatures. It guises itself to be complex but ended up dumbing the whole thing out. Visual effects could be better.
the only thing redeemable about this movie is Papa P on a tank top

Ang daming gustong sabihin, pero wala namang impact. I'd appreciate it more if they just focused on one timeline and on the killer aspect. It relies on jumpscares too much. The dialogues are also awkward - trying too hard.The acting of JC Santos was so good though!

The nonlinear structure, intercutting with three different timelines, finding the connection with its sometimes steady or stagnant pacing, finds its way nowhere near home. A must-be realization for Enrico Santos, the screenwriter.The killing never stops, but producing a big project with magnificent visuals with, no disrespect, a very disappointing writing shall stop. Forty-five minutes into the cinema, the film finally makes sense that the intro is trying to foreshadow — manlalakbays.No question about it. However, the use of jump scares to prolong the first act of the film is way too traditional or 2000s. Those do not contribute nor give any hint at all on why Piolo is in search of answers to their three generations of Mallari’s story. Admittedly, the first hour can be shortened to 15-25 minutes. Remove the jump scares. Just do not feed anything information through visuals; then that alone is enough for the audience to feel the genre. A bummer, still, is the used dialogues to tell a piece of information about either the timeline of the present or the story of past Piolo generations. It could have used the very evident big budget to convey information through visuals instead of throwing lines. Imagine, the film is visually pleasing and plausible, but it does not give anything or help in the progress of the plot. Such, such a waste of opportunity.The detour part of this journey is beauty — production visuals and cinematography.All-in production design. The worlds, as in three different timelines, are well put together. No one dares to refute or even question its costume or the artistic choice; the use of wardrobes and prosthetics. It speaks so much about how the audience accepts the world is shown, displayed, and given to them. Not an easy task to build a world that the audience can easily comprehend, but Mallari does it, and mind you, building THREE TIMELINES. Moreover, the sound design and music score need recognition. Although the need for a revisit in sound mixing due to its inconsistent loudness is a must, it still is a world-class quality. These perfectly and exactly convey the emotion of the characters, as well as the atmosphere of different sequences. Neither a riser nor a drone are instruments or techniques used in the film. An example is the use of bells as a score while killing the landlord in 1812.Feels bad for Piolo Pascual in a good manner. He looks exhausted by performing three characters with different distinctive personalities but conveys it justly and rightly. He may soon retire after pulling off such a performance in Mallari. No one can do that.Despite the negatives, the film counters its flaws through a good, well-thought mise-en-scene. The job of director does well in directing, putting all together by using each department’s strengths while masquerading its lows.In simple terms, the film is in the right hands, the right job, and the right driver. Writing aside due to its being subpar, all goes well. The audience just needs to learn and get used to it.

Mallari successfully weaved an intricate tale of horror w/ a dash of sci-fi & folklore. It's heart however, which is a tale of love, is actually what prevented me 4m giving it a higher score. It set back its own visual myth by excessive jump scares and didacticism.Pasimplehin natin, minurder ni Enrico Santos yung sarili niyang script sa dulo with cheesy declarations na para bang bigla akong nanood ng Cathy Garcia Molina film. Yung shift gear ni Derrick Cabrido to borderline campy sa dulo eh magegets mo, ito parang tinamad o nilagnat nung sa dulo. Even though it draws inspiration from Insidious and Suspiria, it has managed to be unique and memorable. Di ba, mga ka-sisiw?

The concept of having three generations of Mallari, delving on folklore and catholicism is the strength of this film. Although it was based from the true story of Fr. Severino Mallari's serial killing, it was fictionalized by creating a generation of Mallari to show how love and curse overlap over the course of time. Is curse inevitable, is anything done for love be justified, are the existential questions that can be seen with the acts of the three main characters. However, despite its good points, it has to be said that it has dumb and unnecessary parts for the sake of being called horror, like most horror films, of course. It holds so much potential. Maybe that's why it's ambitious for wanting a lot to happen. Glad that transitions are good in the middle because the beginning seemed shaky to me due to its overuse of jumpscares (that are, by the way, predictable). Also, I see that it has to involve folklore, but does it really have to include the scene of Facunda transforming into a manananggal (just one of the many weird stuff)? The belief of killing to save more lives is enough to incorporate it. As to script, it's as if there's not much research on language use. As a Kapampangan, the sudden switch from Filipino to Kapampangan to Filipino again didn't seem natural, as if it was only used to show it explored the setting but failed nonetheless. The usage of Tagalog as to period is a bit inappropriate as well.Overall, the attempt to tell the story of the first serial killer in the Philippines in a creative way is something I can appreciate. I just wish it's more psychological.

This film earns every praise. From the cinematography, direction, acting, color grading, editing, sound design, and musical score, this is unlike any Filipino horror film in recent history. While the writing and handling of multiple timelines can sometimes feel jarring, it was redeemed by its dark tone, atmosphere, twists, and a story that feels unique and very ambitious. Piolo Pascual is excellent in portraying the three lead characters. But the real surprise here is JC Santos, who gave an impressive performance as Brother Lucas. The rest of the cast gave it their all, too. The theme song for this film by juan karlos and Quest is *chef's kiss*
oh god… excellent visuals, unique non linear structure (which i liked!), and a gagging performance from piolo pascual. MAN

relied too much on jumpscares and story was kinda similar to nocebo however, pao orendain’s lensing and luscious cinematography is FUCKING AMAZING!!!!!!!! DESERVE ANG BEST CINEMATOGRAPHY PATI NA RIN PRODUCTION DESIGN

would have been perfect if it wasn’t for the laughably bad cgi. nevertheless, watching this gave me so much hope for ph horror films. mallari’s story, production design, scoring, and of course, piolo’s acting were all so impressive.

Padre Severino Mallari is the first document serial killer from the Philippines with 57 victims under his name. It was believed that his mother was cursed thats why Mallari resorted to unaliving to counter the black magic.What really left an impression for me from this film is the line saying, we are all Severino. Parang sinasabi sa atin na lahat tayo ay may bersyon ng sarili nating halimaw. And this clearly seen in the movie. His mother’s curse had its own form. Years later the curse takes on a different form when it moves to its next body. And along those lines we discover how intergenerational trauma is passed on.At the same time it lets us explore the deep end of what we can do when we are pushed to the brink. How much of ourselves we are willing to sacrifice in order to save a loved one. Blurring the lines between right and wrong. At napakagaling ni Piolo Pascual having to portray 3 different characters struggling along those lines.Hindi ako as much a big fan of jump scares but i appreciate it when done well. But not so much on this movie and the sound design made it a bit more cliche. Although i greatly appreciate the score though, mas nadagdagan ang tension and atmosphere ng mga scenes na nakakatakot. This film excels in a lot of its technical aspects, from cinematography, production design, costumes and editing. And it makes it worth the cinema ticket to watch this on the big screen.Was really impressed at Mallari. Shoutout sa katabi ko kanina sa cinema na di ko kilala na tumalon sa kanyang upuan after one of the jump scares.

This movie is only a fun watch if you are in the cinema with everyone laughing and screaming. Production design is also great.But by itself without spoiling anything the film is both obtuse/confusing and over explained at the same time.Also it feels kinda lazy in the way it portrayed the local filipino villagers as this evil pagan force that is against the "good" of the catholic church and manipulates people to do evil things.It's like it wanted to show the desperation of these people and how they fight back- but decided not to resulting into this demonized portrayal of local culture and beliefs which sucks.

Best Filipino movie I’ve ever watched! I believe that it can actually compete with international movies, that’s how good of a film Mallari is. Stunning performances from Piolo Pascual and JC Santos. They’ll definitely bag the Best Actor and Best Supporting Actor award.

+ Top-tier actong from Piolo (3 generations), Janella, Elisse, Gloria Diaz, and JC santos+ i love how they designed the setting, it was effective in making the scenario unsettling.+ the arrangement of the plot+ how they added filipino lore the story, which is bagay for the theme— napaka unnecessary ng jumpscares, it would've been effective if the cgi/makeup was good, but it's not— it would have been better if they focused on the thrill instead of jumpscares— the manananggal scene and the wolf: the cgi was too cringe. hope they made thought of something different, lesser cgi.

ganda ng story telling lalo na yung nareveal lahat ng back story dun sa timeline na nagkasama sama lahat ng generation, but there’s really something (that i can’t point out) that made me kind of lose my engagement in the movie half way thru. in short, may part talaga na inantok ko ako.nonetheless, napaka galing ng buong cast. the musical scoring was insane! i love it so much and the cinematography is god tier!

i looooved watching this pero i have a lot of totz....obviously anlaki ng budget az andaming partner/sponsor pero i think that was kind of its downfall also?like for example dahil may pambayad, nagcast ng napakalaking star na si papa p. i dont think this role was for him and sobrang nakulangan ako sa acting niya for 2/3 of the duration. honestly the muchachas ate him up sa mga scenes nila together. love them ang talented nila <3and then isa pa yung chemistry nila ni janella salvador. first of all, ang weird lang kasi parang super different generations sila ng actors, and second of all wala lang talaga silang chemistry like nde ko maramdaman na totoo yung nangyayari sa screen!tapooos finally may budget for matinding cgi and actually bet ko ang pagkagawa dun sa eyeless ghosts (literally my #1 fear) KASO ginamitan rin nila ng cgi si ms gloria diaz and di siya kasing ganda nung ghosts. feeling ko lang mas effective ang practical fx sa ganun especially since parang matandang kandila na natutunaw na ang look na habol (similar to the matanda sa X). seeing poor editing really takes you out of the experience :(sa screenplay side naman, i think visually, maganda ang kanyang ginawa sa larger plotline kaso yung dialogue talaga medyo nakakatanga. hindi ko magets bakit may napakagen z na dialogue. para ba maemphasize na yun yung modern timeline? i think it would have worked without that though kasi napakaiba naman ng costume and set design ng 1940s timeline???? ewan iritado lang ako sa masyadong chronically online dialogue kasi it really dates a film and kind of yun nga.... takes me out of the experience.ang weird rin ng representation sa lgbt+ community. i think they were trying to be woke pero why naman ganun pagkasulat sa kanya? a flighty gay person who everyone knows is a sex worker catering to foreigners......?!?!?!? yan pa lang naaalala ko for now so might edit pag meron pa. overall i enjoyed it pero this really would have been better with another lead actor. though some things are very similar sa The Dream Thieves by Maggie Stievfater, i think medyo original naman ang kanyang idea :)
