I could have given MALLARI a perfect score of 5 but to call it a cinematic from hell masterpiece is a big no. The narrative seems to be my reservation here. Not really a fan of time travel except for SOMEWHERE IN TIME where the narrative is neatly tied up and HAPLOS. There are times that it's rather confusing and how I wish D Cabrido divided the time frame from the first time Fr MALLARI appeared in 1800s to 1940s ended with the present times. What was served on the plate was a palabok about the Filipino mythological creatures and to tell more about it will spoil the fun. Find out how Donya Facunda played by Gloria Diaz the mother of Fr. Mallari lived for so long. The Gregorian chant, music, production design are all top notch! And that was one helluva performance of Piolo Pascual. Two scenes that stand out for me his dance sequence with Gloria Diaz and his breakdown scene where you can spot also the evil side of him.Btw that house in Pampanga and the image of St. Bartholomew really creeped me out! All in all an excellent Pinoy horror flick and I'm glad Warner Bros distributed it.

10 Thoughts on 2023 MMFF entry"Mallari" starring Piolo Pascual, Janella Salvador and JC Santos.1. Honestly I didn't find it scary. It had all the classic Pinoy horror tropes but what got me was the edgy concept by the second half.2. Didn't see any trailer prior watching and I thought it's just a murder mystery. Without spoilers, crazy elements were thrown in the mix!3. There were lots of cheap jumpscares and creepy vibe.4. Not a fan of the special and practical effects used as it's quite laughable. That wig and facial hair's hideous.5. Paired with Janella Salvador and Elisse Joson, they could've picked someone that's Piolo's age.6. JC Santos was really outstanding.7. "Ang tao ay kabuuan ng kanyang desisyon"8. "Walang Diyos sa gabi" was on-loop in my head when I got home.9. So right now, nasan ang sisiw??10. This is Piolo Pascual in multiverse of madness.

It's no wonder that the huge studio outfit Warner Bros. Pictures Philippines distributed Derick Cabrido's timeline-jumping horror flick. After all, it's riveting and perfect for mass consumption. "MALLARI", partly-historical, partly-fictional, horrifies with its convoluted yet easy-to-follow storylines of three generations amid murder, mystery, and supernatural folklore. Piolo Pascual brilliantly plays three different characters that are well-meshed in its narrative. Its thrilling score and effective jump scares (although I wish there's more slow burn approach) make a good form that we don't usually experience in most Pinoy horror films. However, there's that miss of questionable mesh on time travel and astral projection and the pitfalls of telling vs. showing narrative technique that makes the execution a bit dull. The third act redeems itself with its intense buildup and that eerie final frame serving a nod to the endless horrors of society.San Bartolome. Doña Facunda. Magalang. Di ba, isang sumpa ang magmahal? (Isn't loving a curse?). 3.5/5 folks!

Nakamamahanga at nakakakilabot. Nakamamangha kasi kaya pala nating gumawa ng ganitong klase ng pelikulang makakasabay sa agos ng modernong pagkekwento. Nakakakilabot dahil ang kwentong ginamit ay may hango sa katotohanan at nakaugat sa mga bagay na kinatatakutan ng mga Pilipino.This film reinvents how Filipino horror stories were told. Marami ng pelikula ang patungkol sa mga kwento at paniniwala ng mga Pilipino pero ibang klaseng takot ang naramdaman ko rito. They utilized those elements properly and effectively.Ang pelikula ay isang malaking paglalakbay. Ginawa nila tayong manlalakbay dahil sinama nila tayo sa pag-aalam ng misteryo at sikreto sa likod ng pamilya Mallari. Sinigurado nila na mararamdaman natin ang kanilang mararanasan, makikita, at malalaman.Nakadagdag din ang magandang cinematography sa pagbuo ng intriguing na atmosphere. Nakapagbigay kilabot ang scoring para mas matakot ka pa lalo. Paniniwalaan mo ang kanilang mga practical effects na ginamit. Ilan lamang ang mga ito sa nakapagdala sa atin sa kanilang mundo. Each timeline has its distinct feel and tone, at napanindigan ito ng mga tao sa likod at harap ng kamera para masiguro na iba-iba sa pakiramdam ng manonood ang bawat panahong pinapasukan nila. Dinadala nila tayo sa iba't ibang panahon at mararamdaman mo talaga ito.Piolo Pascual definitely gave his A-game into this performance. He knew how to give that flare and nuance that will make his three portrayals different from each other. Kaya ka niyang palungkutin, pakabahin, at takutin. He is deserving to get recognition and appreciation because of his performance. He deserves that best actor award. Magagaling din ang mga ibang karakter at bagay ito sa mga artistang gumanap sa kanila. Janella Salvador had this sense of style na siya lang makakapagpamalas. Geraldine Villamil knew how to evoke terror. Elisse Joson blew my mind with her polished attitude. Ms. Gloria Diaz gave something that we never see from her until now. But out of all of the supporting characters, Jc Santos provided the most shocking performance. Dapat mong abangan ang kanyang pagganap dahil madadala ka sa kanya nang sobra.Most importantly, ang pinakanagustuhan ko sa pelikula na ito ay ang kanyang mensahe. Hindi lang siya about sa kuro-kuro ng sambayanan kundi pinakita rin dito ang mga hirap ng pamilya at ano ang makakaya mong ibigay para mapuna ang mga ito.This is a historical story of a family trying to escape from the terrors of the past that continue to creeps the present and that could greatly affect the future. With all that in mind, they knew how to tie all of it together in a jaw-dropping ending. Marami ang hindi ko inakala sa pelikulang ito. Hindi ko inakala na ganito ang kanyang kwento. Hindi ko inakala na sisigaw at matatakot ako nang sobra. At higit sa lahat, hindi ko inakala na makagagawa ang Pilipino ng ganitong klase ng pelikula. This is a film made by Filipinos based on Filipino horror stories that all Filipinos should be proud of. This is the new standard for Filipino Horror.

Two Piolos wrestling each other? Now that’s cinema!(Spoilers incoming)This almost worked. The 1800s sequences, in particular, are the film’s shining moments. It was creepy and almost compelling — the occult infiltrating Christianity/the oppressed tearing down the elite from the inside are proof that this should’ve been a period piece.Still, this particular section of the film is also riddled with sins. The crux of it (showing how Father Severino started with his murder spree) was believable but was not strong enough. You mean, Father Severino is so downtrodden in faith that he resorted to do…that? In one request? The film didn’t even allow the character to explore options or resist. A film about a crisis of faith? What! A missed opportunity. He was just a piece of this convoluted puzzle. And when his faith was shattered. No one batted an eye. His relationship with his mother wasn’t explored enough nor who Father Severino really is — again why this should’ve been a period piece that began with his childhood.Well, this was tooled to be commercially successful and how else to fulfill that but peppering with deadly tropes — time travel, astral projection, love is also a curse shenanigans, innocent ghosts who also like scaring people for the heck of it, a dozen of jump scares, and TikTok humor? Don’t get me wrong. This was so much fun! Especially with a packed theater.Mallari, unfortunately, hacked into many elements but only managed a minor cut.
A horror movie that I actually enjoyed. Would give a 5 buuuut the manananggal scene was ehh

from the get-go, mallari works with an interesting premise: the first documented serial killer in the country. it takes the story a step further by introducing two other timelines, with characters that interact through lucid dreaming. the story is weaved together spectacularly, as the threads among such time periods felt smooth and weren’t forced. the concept is set up nicely, providing sufficient suspense to keep one hooked throughout the movie. i guess my most major issue with it is its framing…

we need of ph horror films like this - i think the movie's strength was that it was able to use existing information based on a real story and connect it to a fictional modern one in a way that isn't cheesy or over done- jc santos in roles like this pls ... pls ... he did such a great job with this film and made sure everyone knew he isn't an actor that's only good in…

While it does, at points, play like a pastiche of the most well-known genre tropes (not just horror), I am willing to overlook that nature of Mallari as what we get here, beyond the clichés, is a very meaty and layered story with pensive meditations on the bounds of a person’s love and familial loyalty. As the film was running I was thinking of how they were going to resolve the story and while I couldn’t, at the time, pinpoint how I would want the story to wrap up, I could very well list a handful of ways how I wouldn’t want the film to end and, without spoiling anything, I think they really stuck the landing with that ending.We may have different tastes and what we look for in films may be different but, Mallari, as a whole, is a film that just works, at least for me. I definitely recommend seeing this.

Gorgeous production; it definitely surpassed my expectations a little bit, considering that it was a locally-made film. This is noteworthy as I don't watch them that often.However, it is also different from what I expected. I was anticipating something of a biopic, telling the story of the first-ever recorded PH serial killer. The direction that the movie took was a bit different, but it's fine, as it was still interesting.For me, the jump scares were not that effective. Considering that it is a high-budget and relatively costly production, you would expect great ones, but most of them were just cheap jump scares carried by loud sounds. The film also focused on too many genres, such as family, horror, comedy, and fantasy, to name a few. I wish those concepts were not overloaded so that we could focus more on the lore.The character of Lucas (JC Santos) was not that convincing, given that he had a huge role. It felt lackluster due to his character's development.The pacing and direction were mediocre at best. There were some highs where the theater was excited about what events might unfold next, screaming and just being hyped. However, there were also disadvantages, such as in the first act where the film was kinda hard to follow.On a positive note, the concept itself was enticing since it's about horror (my favorite genre), and the Philippine mythology was also showcased well.Piolo Pascual also looked great and proved himself to be a versatile actor. His supporting cast also did really well, providing twists and more diversity.All in all, the concept was interesting; it just was not executed to its fullest. Elements were overloaded, and it was a bit hard to follow, but the cast was great, and the production is definitely a level up from its predecessors.

Piolo Pascual's portrayals of the three characters are mostly inconsistent and lacking nuance. There are scenes where his Johnrey and his Jonathan are almost alike. When his Severino and his Jonathan meet in one of the crucial scenes, the former seems to have become the latter. He is also Jonathan. Or Piolo. There's one scene, though, where he transforms completely. Regardless of how the scene is set-up and built to be this important, his portrayal of this character is utterly diabolical. So good. I won't spoil. You'll know what I mean when you see the film. It is JC Santos who is consistently impressive in the film. His evolution comes to a riveting performance deserving of recognition. Watch out for this one scene where he outshines his co-actor. The film could have done more in terms of VFX. Its score could have been tempered for a more dramatic effect, but despite what the film lacks, it achieves something remarkable for the genre. Enrico Santos wrote a screenplay that weaves an interesting mix of the horror and the time-travel narrative. The script is complemented with well-paced execution and engaging scenes. Overall, Mallari is a compelling watch--a Pinoy genre film not easy to forget.

So little is known about the almost unbelievable true story of serial killer priest Fr. Severino Mallari that it's only logical to take liberties with it. The team behind the film Mallari took MANY liberties, and they mostly work (the use of dark folklore is particularly enticing), though one of the main conceits (an ability inherited through the character's bloodline) is rather questionable in terms of its utility and necessity. Initially, I wanted to watch this film because it was my surname (which doesn't happen often) and because of the premise (how do they make a film out of the country's first serial killer who was a priest?) MALLARI How far will you go just to keep your loved ones alive? One of the best horror films I have ever watched. It is a three-timeline story that is all being connected by a single superstition. The story revolves around Fr. Severino Mallari, a true-to-life priest from Pampanga in 1812 and is the first ever documented serial killer in the Philippines. Then fictional characters Johnrey Mallari, a documentarist in 1948, and Jonathan Mallari, a doctor in the present day.…

The commendable cinematography paints a visually arresting landscape, showcasing a keen eye for detail in every scene. However, the film's occasional dependence on excessively loud sounds for an eerie effect raises concerns about its subtlety and may potentially overpower the audience's senses.While the narrative unfolds, numerous unnecessary jump scares seem to be sprinkled throughout. The inclusion of cheesy dialogue exchanges between Agnes and Jonathan, these moments, rather than enhancing the story, feel gratuitous and detract from the overall viewing experience.Despite these drawbacks, this film manages to reach a level of acceptability. However, there are certain parts that leave some viewers questioning the subtlety of its approach.Undoubtedly, Johnrey is my bias. He's the only one tunay, palaban, at makabayan <3[By the way, opting for a late-night cinema screening at 10:45 PM added a dimension to the viewing experience.]

Mallari highly delivered the fright taking this historically accurate character and building this disturbing world that bridges both "sci-fi" and Philippine folklore. It had the mass appeal of a true horror flick (including the character's dumb decisions) but still made sure that there were no loose ends. Even with these merits, it suffered a few mishaps. In the performances, Piolo did his best portraying these three separate individuals from different timelines but it did not help that JC Santos outacted him in almost all of their scenes together. The 3 characters also needed a bit more distinction but still a commendable performance nonetheless. But probably the biggest blunder is how it was overscored. The source material I believe can shine by itself without us being dictated by the score on where to get scared. And the "manananggal" too was a choice. But again, the future is bright or shall I say darker  if this is the direction our horror flicks will go to.

"Walang Diyos sa gabi."MALLARI has reached a spot that the other recent Filipino horror films cannot touch. At first, I was a bit skeptical on how the three timelines will be showcased properly in a 2-hour film yet the movie surprised me on how cohesive it is. The plot is out of this world for a typical horror film but it surprisingly accomplished its goal. In a very well manner at that. The scoring and the continuous shots are also superb, creating an eerie atmosphere throughout the duration of the film, especially in the intense scenes. However, some special effects didn't work but I'll let it pass as the story and the actors really did well to compensate for it.Lastly, I want to say that:Felicity, you are a mother to many!

An exceptional horror-thriller film about extreme determination, but for the wrong reasons. I'm so happy that the Philippine entertainment industry has come out of its cocoon and is now ready to conquer the larger global market for entertainment content. Mallari is such a stunner. Editing made a seamless integration of time jump elements. The acting is superb; Piolo is exceptional in his portrayal of the three Mallaris. His short portrayal of the demonic hallucinations, though, was chef's kiss. The screenplay kept me thinking about how the movie would end, even until the last 5 minutes. My main takeaway from this movie is that peace as a goal, when achieved by killing socially undesirable people, is diabolical. And while we may have our own personal thoughts of unaliving bad people for the sake of a better society, it is our demons that are speaking for us. Fundamentally, the movie is a satirical expression of our human follies, including extreme desire, sanctimony, and lack of good judgement.

“‘Di ba’t isang sumpa ang magmahal?”Mallari does not only showcase the story of the infamous Fr. Severino Mallari, but also delves into the lives of men from succeeding generations of his clan. The first descendant, Johnrey, a documentary filmmaker in post World War II Philippines, and the second being Jonathan De Dios, a doctor and the lead protagonist of the film. The two descendants of Fr. Severino try to discover their family’s darkest secret, which most likely has contributed to the killings and disappearances in Magalang, Pampanga.All three generations of the Mallari clan are played by Piolo Pascual, which is perceived to be difficult parts to play. However, Pascual was able to to help distinguish one generation from another and yet was able to establish the connection between all three characters.What also is depicted in the movie is the presence of important female figures in each of the Mallari men’s lives: Dona Facunda, Fr. Severino’s mother played by Ms. Gloria Diaz, Felicity, Johnrey’s wife played by Elisse Joson, and Agnes, Jonathan’s fiancee played by Janella Salvador. All three actresses gave the three women their respective well-defined characters which was able to show how each Mallari’s love for these women had urged them to take greater lengths, even if it will cost them their own morals.JC Santos does an excellent job in portraying Brother Lucas in the likeness of Brutus from Shakespeare’s Julius Caesar, as he showcases his character’s loyalty and later betrayal to Pascual’s Dr. Jonathan.The film may remind one of Luca Guadagnino’s Bones and All (2022) with its presence of common themes such as gore and manslaughter. It is also important to note how both Carido and Guadagnino have commonly used manslaughter as a dark metaphor for love as a motive of sacrifice and self-discovery, which the former has executed very well and evidently in Mallari (2023).It also bears similarities with Edgar Wright’s Last Night in Soho (2021) not just with the presence of gore and manslaughter, but also with the key theme of time travel, which the two Mallari descendants have used in order to learn about the dark secret of their family for this film.The film had a well-organized flow of events, as well as a smooth transition in between time periods. It was able to give me and other viewers proper context and a good idea on how to let the story unfold and think about what could happen next. However, Jonathan’s arc was very anti-climactic towards the end yet it established his arc as an anti-hero.Another thing to love about this film is that not only did it have Gothic themes and the use of the Catholic faith, which are associated as Western literary and cultural elements, but it also incorporated the use of Filipino folk medicine and faith healing, which are indigenous Filipino cultural elements, as important parts of the film.In conclusion, Mallari (2023) was a great watch, and it definitely deserved the accolades. Not only did it bring justice to a dark love metaphor, but it also presented and promoted Filipino culture through folk medicine as key horror elements. It is a must watch for traditional Filipino horror movie buffs and those in need of a fresh face to Filipino horror films.[Metro Manila Film Festival 2023]

It's actually a well made film if going to be compared to the last two decades of modern Filipino cinema. It's also fine if it doesn't go to the realistic, intimate retelling of the Philippines first ever recorded and controversial serial killer ala Fincher's Zodiac and instead went into a fantastical route ala Burton's Sleepy Hollow; cinema's main purpose afterall, first and foremost, is to entertain audiences and bring them into the realm of unknown. I would even recommend this as one to see among the current available selection of what to watch in the latest Manila Film festival. Cabrido is adept at sensationalizing history into folk horror to a journeyman’s appeal, rendering our first recorded serial killings as that of collateral damage from Spanish and American colonial oppression. A really formally engrossing work, but potency doesn’t just stem from imagination. As for every one step this film takes forward, it takes two steps back. For Mallari, The presence of a tangible threat stems from our protagonist’s dream, and the fact that he can see.. zombies? It deeply fails to create a sense of narrative urgency it needed until about halfway through, where suddenly it livens up its form and picks up a lot of heat. This is a movie that believes spectacle can be derived from the eruption of background music and a jagged, accelerated frame, which is ironic considering how listless it is a unit.

Mallari was kind of a swing and a miss but, well, it was a glorious swing nonetheless. I always complain about majority of the mainstream Filipino movies because they always seem so uninspired. They're usually either tired recreations of frustratingly melodramatic stories I've seen a million times over or they're copies of recently popular movies produced by other countries with a better film scene. So I have to commend Roderick Cabrido and the rest of the filmmakers who worked on…

The concept was great but there were so many ideas introduced that it all got so convoluted. I came for a biopic of Padre Mallari but I got manananggal, kulam, etc. Although it was great that they added Filipino Mythology on the plot, it still feels like there were tons of ideas thrown around that it got so jarring. I love the idea of astral projection and time travel as it is not often seen in Filipino Horror movies, however, I feel like it got too much that you'd think this is not about Padre Mallari anymore. Also, I don't also feel any chemistry between Piolo and Janella. They feel more like Uncle-Niece whenever they're together. And although, it's been instilled multiple times that Jonathan (Piolo) is obsessed with Agnes (Janella), I still don't feel it. Like they were not able to translate it on screen. Also the theater in Evia fucked up the sound system so all through out the film, I was in a sour mood.Furthermore, It's been a while since I've actually watch a Pinoy Horror film so I was amazed by the camerawork. I think this could've been great as a series rather than a movie to fully tackle what they wanted to portray.

MMFF Marathon Disclaimer:I went in blind to all MMFF entries this year, no idea on it but the poster, didn't even check the genres. So expect me being surprised on most things.I liked it just because I love Piolo Pascual and JC Santos (most of all JC, but let's talk about that later) but I gotta admit storytelling of this has lots of room to improve.It had a lot of jumpscares from ghosts that didn't lead to anywhere. I expected some payoff on the ghosts other than who they were, which was obvious on the getgo.When it was a slasher horror by the first act I was engaged gotta admit, but when the second act started and the time-traveling sci-fi direction went on the film kinda lost me. And when it went more fantastical by the third act by introducing witchcraft and a literal "manananggal" it lost me completely.As this is inspired from real events, I wish they just added upon the plot inspiration since that is an interesting story itself. I was just put-off on the closing title cards where they debunked their own story just to clarify the real story, because it kind of defeated the film. I feel like they accepted that the past 2 hours were fictional but then opening titles said it was inspired from true events.On the brighter side I saw a LOT of improvements here. Color grade was stellar, and lighting design. Night scenes were still visible (ehem hollywood for making night scenes literal darkness), also the VFX and make-up for the spirits were BEAUTIFUL, the "manananggal" part, not so much. Also, the production design. Set served. The amount of detail put into that was STELLAR, I was nitpicking even the wax drips of candles and they were accurate and realistic, very well-thought.Also, Piolo Pascual delivered on different nuances of different eras which made his performance very distinct. Without reintroducing who is who even with change of wardrobe, I knew who he was just by posture and speech. But what impressed me more is JC Santos, both sides of the coin in the soft-spoken to the gnarly side he delivered. The plot twist was underwhelming but his performance gave it a bit of value added.Addendum:One dialogue didn't sit with me after they killed off Didi, it's along the lines of: "She's a sex worker, she's a plague to society". EXCUSE ME SIR SEX WORK IS WORK. IF SHE'S A SCAMMER USE THE TERM BUT SEX WORKERS ARE NOT PLAGUES OF SOCIETY. Anyways, that's just a small hunch of "????" from me.

Mallari uses almost every kind of horror there is to separate itself from previous movies, that primarily used religion to scare or to suspend belief, of which, there are many. Using local history and folklore always gives a unique touch to a film; Mallari even highlights JC Santos (who plays Lucas) using his Kapampangan fluency. However, the CGI used can still improve; I think prosthetics are convincing for such close-up shots. Also, Piolo Pascual, despite mentioning he had an…

the potential!!!!!!!!! a movie featuring the philippines’ first serial killer, who preceded jack the ripper by 50 years (according to the movie anyway) with an amazing score and great production value (the sets, costumes) was soiled by its inability to stick to one genre, the occasionally cheesy line, and the ending+ also has the most basic proposal scene

Watched during the 2023 Metro Manila Film FestivalIf someone caught me being m*rdered by Piolo Pascual, then that's on ME, do NOT arrest him!Went into this thinking it would be a retelling or highlighting the murders or the actual Severino Mallari's process as a serial killer, so that one bit admittedly let me down, but I'm aware that's a me problem. *That aside, wow what a film. I truly went into it blind and admittedly I am not a fan of horrors so this is your pass to bash me or just take what I say with a grain of salt. I am a fan of the time-travelling aspect, so I appreciated seeing that in the film. It was really interesting to see the ties between two distant pasts and the present entwined with family ties, fate, withcraft and all that... I loved it! I think that Piolo was fucking amazing in his triple roles, we are so blessed to have him in such a role on the big screen today. JC Santos truly deserved his Best Supporting Actor win, he is truly insane in this.It's kinda unfortunate the jumpscare horror elements did not really lead to anything, I feel the film could've made do with less of that or made these horror elements mean something than just cheap thrills. To me, those bits just hindered the atmosphere-building and it bothered me. It was a bit funny to me too though that the scenes that garnered most audience reaction were scenes that just involved people. I am also not a big fan of the ending, but I'll keep it at that for you to discover if you, dear reader, will like it or not.(* Edit: Just heard from my mom that there will be a series adaptation of Fr. Mallari's story with Dennis Trillo leading? I will be there no matter what.)
filipino horror sometimes is amazing once done right. this one belongs to the list of good ones

The devil (heh) may care attitude of Mallari really went to a place of the unidentifiable in Philippine cinema. It got so smart with the fusion of genres and somehow, cheated its way in something that is very interesting and cheeky. The genre mechanics became as polarized and those who found value in it, cared no less and the silliness is a great add-on to its narrative.The thematic journey of defeatist films always has a lot to say about bad decisions and the value of good as non-existent. Case in point, Christian Tafdrup's 2022 psychological horror thriller film, Speak No Evil. Said film excessively warns the audience about the eventual demise of the couple, the acceptance of one's fate just sets in. Mallari though, tries to fight back with its barbs and your usual good should always win over evil.It's funny that the whole point of the film had an underlying message that is extremely familiar in the recent and current political climate in the Philippines. The characters are represented by people, factions, and the entire nation. It's a sight for social media and fantasy for the optimist. And despite its hitches in a number of its film elements, it's relatively forgivable with the messaging that it wants to convey..:smcityeastortigas>>

I wish it focused more on the serial killer aspect and Fr. Severino's mental illness. Could have been a great psychological thriller film.But I understand the decision to include Filipino folklore. I just hate how they made it look like Fr. Severino was helpless. As if he had no choice but to kill. As if he deserves pity from the audience. Piolo Pascual had 3 characters to portray but all felt the same. He had some shining moments but overall, he could have done better. JC Santos, on the other hand, never disappoints. What a riveting performance.There were a lot of useless and predictable jumpscares. It was marketed as a horror film but it really wasn't as scary as I thought it would be.Overall, a good attempt but there were too many ideas (serial killing, folklore, ghosts, time travel) that fell all over the place.

I want to say it’s BEST HORROR film of the year, but my thoughts are with: the BEST FILIPINO FILM of the year. The sound design and music score is breathtaking. The writing and direction takes you to a roller coaster ride in which you can hear the audiences squealing, screaming and nervous AF. A friend of mine said, “Hindi ako mahilig sa horror, pero, gustong gusto ko ‘to.’”Piolo gave his performance of the year. A veteran actor that reminded us that our stars are so good. JC Santos and RAFFY Tejada, two theater actors, did not disappoint. But what amazes me is the jumping timelines, spearheaded by a Haunting-of-Hill-House inspired writing: and what threads them together is our dreams, to think that history repeats itself, and it only needs one protagonist to sleepwalk and realize that his worst nightmare has become the reality in his waking life.Even the set design is built from scratch. Mallari threads as our newest breed of horror, giving us something new to look forward with the Filipino indie-mainstream scene. I’d like to believe we are witnessing a renaissance for the elevation of standards of the Filipino film. Walang kupas. Wala silang tinira. Lahat ng takot mo, hawak mo pa rin kalabas. Mero mas nakakatakot and kasakiman ng tao kaysa sa malignong naninirahan dito.At gamang gama ni Piolo ang pagarte dito. Akala mo, ipinanganak ang role na ito para sakanya.

There’s a bit too much to unpack with Mallari, serving too many elements that it takes away from the main narrative, and in turn removes from the scare factor aside from mostly meaningless jumpscares. While we barely even learn of the true origins of the titular character, it’s the production value that really makes the film great, from the visuals, prod design, scoring, and what is probably Piolo Pascual in his best role(s) yet. Despite its setbacks (and unnecessary homophobia/transphobia), Mallari’s production remains to be an impressive standard Filipino cinema should aspire to continue.

Not much is known about priest Juan Severino Mallari, said to be the Philippines' first and only serial killer, but that was all it took to create a feature film for the Metro Manila Film Festival."Mallari" (2023) won four awards at this year's Gabi ng Parangal — 3rd Best Picture, Best Supporting Actor for JC Santos, Best Musical Score, and Best Visual Effects — and of those four it is the latter that appears unconvincing.No doubt that win is attributed to scenes in the latter part of the film as the so-called mystery unravels, but these effects come off as cheesy like the initial jumpscares that build the film.The score by Von De Guzman can be forceful and insistent at times, but it gradually allows the film's horror structure to take charge.However Santos' win is fully well-deserved, an extreme compliment as most of his scenes are with the more seasoned Piolo Pascual and yet he manages to give his character a believable descent.That is not to be hard on Pascual though as he is given the task of juggling three different characters; his charm just happens to be too strong for this foray into horror.There is one scene though where Pascual's dramatic chops shine so bright, and it is during a silent reckoning with his actions as he dances with Gloria Diaz's Facunda, she too committed to the cause of her character.Mallari's story is undoubtedly an intriguing one to tackle, however Enrico Santos' screenplay doesn't do enough to fully utilize that premise and the plotline he decides on.Full published review: www.philstar.com/movies/2023/12/29/2321996/mallari-review-jc-santos-outshines-piolo-pascual-mmff-horror

I can sum it up as “all style, little substance”. Technically, this is a great looking film. The cinematography (my fave part of the movie are the transitions!), the styling, the sets, the grading, the SFX, visually the movie really is on point. However, the movie literally tried to do too much with so many different horror elements coming up that everything felt half baked. A slasher with a priest turning evil? Nice. Three different characters from three different time periods and how they are connected? Smart. But when all the supernatural stuff came in, the movie went so overboard with the story that it went nowhere. But if you wanna watch Piolo Pascual being hot af x3? Go watch it.

Instead of an interesting exploration of the Philippines' only priest-turned-serial killer, MALLARI devolves into a convolution of time travel, astral projection, and local folklore. It misses to touch on the dark psyche of what could have been a good subject in film. The use of horror and jump scares get in the way of the narrative; pulling the audience farther from what could have been a real terror: that of serial killer in an institution Filipinos revere.

A unique story that is a breath of fresh air for us pinoy horror fans. I also like how the film uses scoring to amplify its horror scenes— much like a lot of slasher films in the 80s. I would like to see more about how Mallari did the killings. Also, it can be too much since there are a lot of backstories but nevertheless, I enjoyed the juxtaposition of local folklore and sci-fi. This makes it more enjoyable to watch compared to its competitors this year.

SPOILER-FREEIncredible direction by Roderick Cabrido, stunning cinematography by Pao Orendain, with amazing performances from the main actors. Mallari is a film with three different storylines that met halfway and were easy to follow because the writing, direction, acting, and cinematography were all spot on. I absolutely loved it. The effects were still a little bit wonky but that was only a small part of the film. There were three scenes in particular that made me fall in love with the film, but I won't write them here as this is a spoiler-free review. My final thoughts are that I would definitely watch this again, it was all executed beautifully.

Diba, isang sumpa ang mag-mahal?this review is coming from someone who loves reviewing films as if it's a job. i had the chance to watch this on big screen. don't get me wrong, this movie is good and all it's glory. but why 2½/5?storyline wise, great! couldn't say anything more other than the fact that the transition from different generations was seamless.cinematography? absolutely yes. perfect color grading that matches the theme, not like those very muted filters they put on films.acting? honestly, wasn't very amazed with it. it's only my opinion, and i love judging other people's acting performance as if i'm a professional critic. i'm not sure if it's because the dialogue/script, because i felt awkwardness when they're saying their lines. but then again, it's piolo's first horror movie, so there is still room for improvement if he wanted to continue this path (i would honestly support him 'cause he's such a beaut on screen). jc was phenomenal! such a versatile actor!sound design? my god, a masterpiece! can't get enough of it! they did an amazing job choosing bgmusic/sounds! kudos for that!was it scary? wouldn't say so, coming from someone who doesn't get scared easily (i do, but only for movies that has exorcism involved in it lol, i always feel like i'm gonna be possessed too). the amount of unnecessary jumpscare is sending me off, there's that one scene that felt like my soul left me, other than that, i ended up predicting what's gonna come next (cause i like doing that, to minimize the jumpscare effect lol).anyway, this is still worth watching! i hope this movie will open up for more international collaboration (imagine my surprise when i saw " warner bros' " on the opening scene).

Mike Flanagan's cinematography meets Arrival meets Parasite.Kidding, it's not fair to the movie to talk about it on the basis of comparisons. The themes are certainly there: generational trauma represented by haunted houses, reflections of the past present and future, and a mangled commentary on class politics. This was admittedly poorly paced, like a run-on sentence. I wish prestige TV was a thing locally because this would have been better fleshed out in a 7-9 episode miniseries, a la The Terror or 1899. The poor pacing resulted in what should have been an interesting premise and strong themes turned to a hodgepodge of ideas.Gorgeously produced and well acted, but with way too much fat to trim off. But like I said in my Smaller and Smaller Circles review, if this paves the way for more serial killer themed local media, let's get at it!!!

MallariInitial Trailer POV: WB will distribute the film, mukhang may mapaptunayan siya sa buong Film Fest. Lumalaban sa matinong production design, cinematography at blend ng practical at CG Effects.Okay. Kahapon pa ako eager isulat to.I left the cinema with pure satisfaction. Everything went really well!The script is superb. Nabigyan nila ng flavor ang isang historical document turned fictional narrative by slowly weaving 3 important characters and importing supporting leads and powerful events who did their part to the overall story. Madami siyang elements pero na-intorduce nila ito in an effective way--nag gu-grow sa audience lahat ng ginagawa nila at mga nangyayari sa pelikula. Naitahi nila nang maayos ito para humantong ang lahat sa isang thought provoking and heart pounding conclusion. The technical choices were powerful. I spot little technical issues, but it doesn’t drag the whole film quality down. Almost perfect and cinematic storytelling nila.Yes, may mga sequences at events na feel ko sana nai-revise or naisama sa final cut. Also wished it was more gory.But overall, it has delivered! (Its way better from the production’s 2022 entry (My Father, Myself))Natakot, nagulat, nalungkot, nainis at nagcheer kami sa mga characters at events. May pinatunayan nga!Ang saya, sobrang satisfying.Gusto ko ulitin!

walang diyos sa gabi.the clock of the story diverges and converges steadily; it gives the characters a chance to tell their side of the story. it frightens, yes. but it critiques, too. the priests and the antiquated beliefs residing within the church. the notion of retribution and whether some monsters are worth killing.sometimes, however, it imposes what it wants to do. there are jumpscares that are too superficial to move the narrative. a trope subversion just for the sake of subverting something: agnes' scream of terror in the hospital that somehow turns into jaded haughtiness as she enters their new home. the end anticipates your disbelief so much that it looks into your eyes almost imploringly.

Mallari is a pretty ambitious film. It's a slasher, also a sci-fi because of the time travel aspect and also a period piece. It's a fictionalized story about Severino Mallari, a parish priest in Pampanga who is the first Filipino serial killer. First, I just wanna say that the visuals were pretty amazing. As a horror fan, I'm glad to say that we are now catching up. Andaming magagandang ideas at concepts sa mga local horror films natin, di nalang tayo paulit-ulit. Praise-worthy ang cinematography and production design dito. The score is amazing, it really fits to the tone of the film. Piolo Pascual really did served, one of his best performances, I like it when he plays characters outside his comfort zone. Also JC Santos is pretty good here, he really deserves that best supporting actor award. First time ko rin na mapanood si Janella Salvador sa big screen, finally she's in a horror movie that doesn't suck. The film does fall into the usual horror cliches unfortunately. First, the jumpscares, there are so many jumpscares here that are just so unnecessary. Ghosts appearing left and right accompanied by a loud sound, without any purpose or significance with the story and most of the time, they are just so predictable. Di naman kasi nakakatakot ang gulat eh, hinay hinay lang din sa paggamit.I also have problems with the script. It does overexplain a lot to the audiences. A noticed a lot of exposition scenes, this film is not for children, please let the audience think and piece together the mystery themselves or just show don't tell.Mallari is an enjoyable horror film with a pretty unique concept, despite doing too much, there are many things here that you will appreciate and as a horror fan, this MMFF is a great start to finally make original and good pinoy horror films.*Ang weird lang para sakin yung mga scenes ni Janella and Piolo, parang mag ama lang sila, sorry

Initially, I found myself being quite nitpicky and complaining about a couple of minor details, visuals, jump scares and effects choices. But as the movie progressed, it grew on me and eventually captured my full insatiable attention. The story pretty much revels in its intruiging mystery. It's bold and deliciously insidious. Its wicked irreverence reminds me of films like The Omen and Rosemary's Baby. Piolo taking on the three roles reminds us of how talented he is as an actor and is pretty much capable of stretching his range. The music is powerful and tickles the horror fan in me with how much it effectively marinated the movie. MALLARI has a spectacular appeal that I enjoyed, and I was also glad to hear, once more, loud screams and reactions from horror cinema audiences. In a really good way, it reminds me of those great Pinoy horror comicbooks from the good old days. MALLARI, judging from its overall package, was a solid entry, it was awesome and wickedly spectacular.

Short Review: Ang Alamat ng DinuguanI like it but not wholly - I think the two major plot concept of the film didn’t gel well for me. Actually, more of they can go separately as I wished this was more of a psychological thriller than a fictional thriller. Some thoughts:- Cast was on the spot! Everyone was really good - even the side characters. And they felt more fleshed out than I expected!- Plot was good … till it wasn’t. But there were really good direction here but somewhere somehow it became off. I think when it was started to do expositions.- There were too on the nose lines and on the nose scenes. The blanket realization irked me the most as it was obvious but the lead had to have a line for it.- Production overall was well made - but I don’t know why but PH media (regardless whether high budget or low) felt cramped/limited. It’s like the invisible wall in video games that makes it feel small.With that said, this had potential and I thoroughly enjoyed it! It will probably be one of my fave MMFF movies this 2023.

im so sorry u can sell to me anything that is folk horror  i loved many things here!!!!! another "everything everywhere all at once" film but idgaf because i enjoy horror, thriller, crime, folklore, religion, period and family drama. i love the many things they tried to do, and i think it worked!i just wish it was more of a "show" than "tell" film. dialogues also tend to state the already obvious. example: when john rey found out that he brought back jonathan's towel, he voiced it out as if the audience couldn't see towel in his hand. characters KEEP speaking out their thought process. it threw me off because (1) real people don't do that, (2) it takes away the mystery, (3) EVERY actor are talented enough, i am sure they can deliver the thoughts and emotions of their characters through their body language and facial expressions alone. mallari is a smart film (at least smarter than many recent filo films), but it sees its audience as stupid or ppl who needs to be spoonfed.THIS IS A PROOF THAT WE NEED MORE PHILIPPINE FOLK HORROR!!!!!!! we don't need to borrow from other countries' horror genre, no need for filipino versions of annabelle, saw, and carrie. our folklore is vast and more interesting!!!!!!

Is it justifiable when a human kills others in the name of justice? To eliminate the evil in this world? Does one person that you love most's life matter more than the lives of others? Are we able to escape the fate that has been sealed long before our parents existence? Is love really the biggest curse of it all? These are all the questions that came to mind as I was watching Mallari. Before I continue, I just wanted to point out that they executed the connection between the 3 generations of Severinos seamlessly. It was really impressive how they wove the stories of the different generations of Mallari into the final fate of the present one. He who determines whether a person is the sum of all his decisions or his mistakes. More than anything I adore films that evokes questions out of me. There's just this juvenile wonder that comes after witnessing a story unfold in front of you. Something about it makes my morale skyrocket. That, for me, is one of the factors I consider when writing about films I watch. In conclusion, I ask of you (to whoever may be reading this, anyone who doesn't have a short attention span like I do), to watch this film. It has a very intriguing plot, features great performances from the leads, tells the story fate or trauma being hereditary, and the gift and curse of love to humans. Also what the actual fuck... Piolo is jaw-droppingly gorgeous AND talented? I knew he was all that, but goddamn did this punch me in the face just how he is that! bitch 100%. JC Santos also absolutely devoured that role of being the blind worshipper and he rightfully won Best Supporting Actor ikdr.

they just missed the opportunity to make it a psychological thriller masterpiece. this movie has the best storytelling of multi-verse/time travelling, i have ever seen in a filipino movie. the biggest downside for me is the forced demonic possession and aswang plot which was very unnecessary to the story. this could have been one of the best filipino horror movie.

My rating is related to the horror aspect, which was what it tried to achieve. I am a horror/thriller sucker so I have really high expectations when it comes to this genre.This film is ambitious and derivative to its core, with everything going all at the same time BUT I think it was able to seamlessly tie all timelines together and Piolo Pascual's acting to each persona is just god-tier. With regards to the horror side, the CGI is just so bad, that 1 scene completely threw the audience off. Jumpscares are there but it's a blend of sci-fi, folklore and history, which was a bit convoluted. Now I understand why JC Santos won Best Supporting Actor; he's beyond scary, he was frightening to watch. 1 question I just had was why Piolo did not win Best Actor with his 3 role portrayals (4 plus the alter-ego). This has potential.

MALLARI (MMFF 2023)Mallari presents an intriguing premise and stunning visuals, complemented by stellar performances from the cast.Piolo has his moments in this film. Embodying three distinct characters is no small feat. Unfortunately, he struggles to convincingly portray the nuanced differences among these characters, leaving one yearning for an acting style akin to James McAvoy in "Split."On the contrary, JC Santos delivers an outstanding performance, effortlessly stealing the spotlight from Piolo.But despite this, the film still struggles to evoke spine-chilling moments. It relies heavily on jump scares that, unfortunately, don't significantly impact the overall storyline.Also, the narrative style of withholding key information, strategically aiming for impactful revelations towards the end, serves as one of its major pitfalls. While effective in building suspense, this approach renders characters—especially Jonathan—somewhat devoid of logical thinking, an odd characteristic given his role as a doctor.Despite these shortcomings, the film remains a worthwhile watch for those seeking a fusion of scares and suspense.SCORE: 2/5#MMFF2023 #MallariMMFF #MallariTheMovie #mallari

Set in three timelines, Mallari is inspired by the first documented serial killer, a small parish priest Fr. Severino Mallari, and how the next generations in his family are influenced by power and madness. The film gave us three Piolo Pascual who embodied three distinct characters from the three timelines and while Mallari surprises local horror fans with its twists and turns and interwoven timelines, the overabundance of cheap jumpscares and tonal mishaps made it too overwhelming and confused about its own identity. The overall production design, scoring, and Pascual's acting are the main highlights of the film. When the timelines switch, it genuinely feels like a different timeline. The nuances among the three Mallaris were all vividly portrayed by Pascual. And yes, even with the horrible-looking beard was justified. My biggest issue with the film is its confused identity. It pastes a pastiche of horror tropes that becomes too much sacrificing the narrative value of the film. Had it carefully chosen a fewer element and given a premium focus on it, the film would have been much better for me.

I rated Mallari 4 stars out of 5 because there are many things I like and one thing I don't.I love how the production played with the colors in Mallari's scenes. You won't get confused about whether you're in Fr. Severino's timeline or with John Rey and Jonathan. The story of Fr. Severino, the first documented serial killer, blended seamlessly with John Rey and Jonathan's narrative.Despite some disappointment with Jonathan's decision in the final part, if you reflect on the beginning and why he investigated Fr. Severino, his decision becomes acceptable.The one thing I dislike about this movie is the excessive jumpscares. Although there are too many, only 2-3 actually startled me. Nevertheless, it remains one of the best Filipino horror films.Piolo (Fr. Severino, John Rey, Jonathan) is a great actor and a strong contender for the best actor award. He truly embodied Fr. Severino, John Rey, and Jonathan. I've seen many of Piolo's movies, but this one truly stood out; he excelled in all these roles.Bro. Lucas and Agnes (JC Santos & Janella Salvador) are also standout performers in this movie. People were screaming during their scenes. JC Santos truly deserves the Best Supporting Actor award. I'm also rooting for Janella to win Best Supporting Actress  but why not her?Hoping for more Filipino movies like this, and I'm begging Mentorque to put Mallari on Netflix or Prime Video, pleaseeeee. Evident sa pelikulang ito na nahasa si Derrick Cabrido sa paggawa ng horror specials sa Kapuso mo, Jessica Soho. Nagagalingan ako na may elementsng deconstruction ang latag dun sa multi-generational representation ng Mallari (Severino, John Ray at Jonathan). Isama na din ang time travel element. Ang hirap ng role ni Piolo dito kasi triple role. I agree na career best performance niya ito. Mahusay din si JC Santos. Surprisingly, nagustuhan ko ang performance ni Janella Salvador dito. Delving into three intertwining timelines and employing a time-traveling twist, "Mallari" presents an ambitious scope. While the writers were able to tame this beast with a narrative that manages to engage and leaving its audiences intrigued, the overreliance on jump scares and the occult fails to tie up effectively with the overall storyline. This heavy-handed (and unnecessary) approach to horror detracts from what could have been a refined, narrative-driven film instead.Dr. Jonathan Mallari de Dios (Piolo Pascual) embarks on a journey to his ancestral home in Magalang, Pampanga, in search of a hidden chamber from his childhood - a chamber purportedly holding a cure for his fiancée's (Janella Salvador) severe illness. Upon arrival, we're introduced to his ancestors: Fr. Juan Severino Mallari (Piolo Pascual), the notorious 19th-century Filipino serial killer, and Johnrey Mallari (Piolo Pascual), a chronicler of World War II in the Philippines for the Americans. As eerie occurrences unfold within the house, it becomes evident that his quest may bring more harm than good to his loved ones.In the realm of fantastical and supernatural cinema like "Mallari," stringent logic isn’t always to be expected. There's always a give and take involved as we're delving into imaginary stuff. Yet, the fundamental plot struggles to find coherence. Elements often feel forced, serving the narrative agenda without solid grounding. The biggest question for us is why is there a need to continue the legacy of murders across time? While the rationale is clear in the 1800s in Fr. Mallari's time, subsequent timelines lack this clarity and cohesion. The handling of time travel also raises eyebrow-raising issues, from small stuff such as our protagonists modern-day attire back in time without issue to seamless communication across eras to bigger issues such as the reasons how the Mallaris are able to go selectively go back in time.However, the film's glaring misstep lies in its gratuitous use of unnecessary horror and jump scares. The continuous barrage of ghostly appearances lacks purpose, serving more to frustrate than thrill. It's apparent why they put this excessive amount in "Mallari" and ironically it backfires by producing the opposite effect. Despite these drawbacks, "Mallari" maintains a level of entertainment. It's fundamentally flawed but manages to strike occasional emotional chords, buoyed by its visually captivating cinematography and commendable performances by Piolo Pascual and JC Santos in particular. Surprisingly, a degree of attachment develops with the main characters, though the film could have greatly benefited from more refinement and streamlining. "Mallari" assumes forced scares are necessary for a fulfilling experience, missing the mark on delivering a cleaner and better narrative in the process.Source: www.reeladvice.net/2023/12/mallari-mmff-movie-review.html

DISRESPECTFUL TO THE VICTIMS.HOW DID YOU MANAGE TO MAKE A FILM DEHUMANIZING A MURDERER MORE THAN HOW A NORMAL PERSON WOULD DEHUMANIZE A MURDERER IN THEIR OWN MIND.If you enter the cinema asking "Why would this murderer kill 57 people? How did he do it? Why is he a priest? What's the significance of his faith to this actions? You'd be left unanswered or simply, disappointed. A lot of the answer you'd get from the story of the first serial murderer in the Philippines ISN'T what you'd expect. Because the film...... ISN'T what you'd think it is, it's a completely boring film. You'd ask, maybe a thrilling reason to his killings maybe? A cold-blooded vigilante? Nah, this film manages to capture every joke of an excuse for a horrible pastor. In one of the worst showcase of fable based "true event" story, this film completely shocked me by how corny and ridiculously blasphemous their written/chosen tale is and how it was executed.First, how did i get "hyped"?1. This was produced by Warner Bros. So obviously, as dumb as i am, i assumed we had done something right cinematically or atleast screenplay-wise.2. Piolo Pascual plays several roles. Piolo's been one of the best at picking which movies to appear in and who's passionate to what they do. Being present in Lav Diaz's films, being the best actor (imo) in Erik Matti's On The Job 1, he is significant in starring and helping produce the most ambitious flicks out there. He is one of my fav actors in the industry and so, i expected such moving performance here and i was left disappointed.3. New director to me, obviously, filmbuffs watches films for directors and being a new director i expected an up-and-coming new prospect to the staling roster of today.4. The plot, i don't think there's no plot better and more interesting in a while.5. MMFF is BACK! They said, It will be FUN they said. Totally taking away a murderer and going fully to the stereotypically plot-twist engaged minds of Filipino cinema watchers. This flick does not move our overall filmography at all even being produced by such prestigious film production. I expected Warner Bros to teach us how to make a proper film, how to fix the wrongs that we do. Nah, they just gave us a big budget of which we wasted to VFX that Filipinos love and never do right, Unneeded plot-twist and the props/design of which is actually one of the few okay things they managed to do. So the visuals are good? Nah the cinematography, blocking, coloring and effort in framing overall just didn't help the film at all. The directing and editing is so abrupt at times as well, even cutting to improper angles or jump cutting without a hint of pace at all. The 3rd act felt so rushed yet so dragged by the end??? No sense of pacing, completely ruining their own thrill in the climax by rushing their cuts and scenes just to complete the slow and boring end to the story.Just an absurd choice of story, obviously this is from the tales they must've heard from the locals and connected it to what seems to be an engaging flick with its unique premise and even unique portrayal. But this just shows that those things are NOTHING without the talent of a director, the invisible string that'll try to make a joke have profound meaning. What the hell even is the physiological conflict in this? What's the profoundness supposed to be? It's a complete waste of a good topic or story to unravel. It's a complete mess in filmmaking and an emotionless try to make something intriguing. I don't recommend watching this (unless you're going to the cinema with the people you're happy with like i did so i left there feeling well nonetheless. How can they dehumanize such inhumane actions to the point that it doesn't seem inhumane anymore? It felt like a joke horror rather than a meaningful or cold story. Korean cinema would EAT this. Hollywood would KILL for this script. It doesn't surprise me that Philippine cinema is not good, obviously. But to ruin a what could be easily-engaging plot? That's just..... criminal.

Mallari is an ambitious film. Based on the story of the first documented Filipino serial killer, the movie could have been a gripping tale of horror and suspense. But it took a different approach and unfortunately, the execution fell a bit short in some parts.Don't get me wrong, the time-travel aspect is certainly interesting. But it left me feeling a bit disjointed and uninvested in the characters. Maybe it's just personal preference, but I prefer subtly eerie horror movies, slowly building up to the big scares that leave me on the edge of my seat and screaming my heart out. Instead, Mallari relied too heavily on jump scares and loud music that didn't quite deliver. It worked on the first few times, but it lost its novelty after a while. I left the cinema not scared shitless, but instead laughing at what just happened.But let's give credit where credit is due - the production value was stunning, sans a few VFX parts. It's easily one of the most visually impressive films from this year's MMFF batch. If only they had stuck to what they were good at and taken more risks than they could fully commit to.Overall, Mallari had so much potential that unfortunately wasn't fully realized. But it's still worth a watch for the visuals and unique take on the Philippine horror genre.Seen at SM City Dasmariñas as part of the 49th Metro Manila Film Festival

An ambitious, centuries-spanning, horror film about the first Filipino serial killer. I don't think any other local film in recent memory has attempted to take on something with this grand of a scope.The film was successful in establishing a sinister atmosphere and setting up the intrigue of how the three timelines intertwine. The non-linear storytelling challenges its viewers and helps keep the suspense alive. Back this up with excellent production and sound design and you have a very promising first half.Unfortunately, the film was not able to sustain its fascinating premise. The infusion of time travel, questionable supernatural elements, and unnecessary jump scares made for a clunky second half. The unraveling of the mystery didn't really feel satisfying and the promise of "the first Filipino serial killer" was not explored to its fullest potential. I feel like this would have been more successful as a character study instead of focusing on the supernatural side.Some elements hold it back from truly achieving greatness but Mallari is a step up from previous MMFF horror entries not named 'Seklusyon' and pushes the boundaries of how good the technical quality of pinoy films could be.

I've been hearing a lot of good reviews about Mallari so I decided to give it a shot as well in this year's Metro Manila Film Festival.The concept of Mallari is very risky especially in the horror genre but it was offered to the viewers as simply satisfying by focusing solely on the story not the scares.The casts were obviously great, they were able to shine each moment they have within minutes and frames. Piolo Pascual had to internalize his characters in a good way since we see different personalities in different people and generations.A horror film that is so good to watch in which we should be proud of. Mallari does it the right way with the scares, philippine folklores, and the bits of history.

There are flaws here and there, and questionable scenes that negate or contradict the story, but hell yeah, I don't give a damn. I like how in the end the main lead's character came to full circle—Mallari is and was, a serial killer, and there is no redemptive way to change history. I'm sure that most of you don't see that angle but once you realize—as the mc broke the third wall, like what Damien did for The Omen—that he decided to become what he is supposed to be, and he embraced it with his eyes wide open then, you'll probably find some appreciation for how this story was told rather than just do the usual "historical" route. Wasn't super scary, but it's a fun experience. Although it could improve more on the editing room.

In this time travelling horror mash up from director Derick Cabrido, Piolo Pascual plays not one, not two, but four different characters from three different timelines.In the first timeline, we follow the newly assigned parish priest, Fr. Severino Mallari (Pascual) and his mother, Doña Facunda (Gloria Diaz) as they both settle in the sleepy town of Magalang, Pampanga, circa 1812. Here, we learn what drove him to become the serial killer that we know today.In the second one set in 1948, we follow his descendant, filmmaker Johnrey Mallari (played again by Pascual) and his wife, Felicity (Elisse Joson), as he investigates the mysterious case of his ancestor, Severino, who has killed 57 victims.In the present time, Dr. Jonathan Mallari De Dios (Pascual) returns to his family's ancestral home in Magalang to search for a way to save his fiancé, Agnes (Janella Salvador) from dying. He believes that the cure lies at the hands of his ancestors, Doña Facunda and Severino Mallari.It's admittedly an interesting concept, as the film presents itself as inspired by the true to life crimes of Juan Severino Mallari, Phillippines' first documented serial killer during the 1800s, predating London's Jack The Ripper by more than 60 years. However, all that potential is sadly wasted in this film.Penned by Enrico Santos and helmed by Derick Cabrido, this horror film feels like a multitude of films stitched together, thanks to its many story arcs and concepts. A big chunk of the film plays out like a slasher flick, as we watch Severino Mallari dispatching a couple of victims along the way. The film also plays around with the idea of time travel and astral projection. A portion of it also feels like a creature feature, while the remaining part is your standard ghost story, as the characters are occasionally terrorized by the souls of Mallari's victims.The film is enjoyable in some parts, but as a whole, it feels convoluted. At times, it even feels confusing. The script tries to make the merging of the overarching story arcs and timelines as smooth as it can, but it can't help but feel overstuffed and too muddled. Enrico Santos' screenplay also didn't fully utilize the concept, although I appreciate the film's outlandishness. Imagine, from a serial killer, we eventually get to see ghosts, witches and aswangs in one sitting. Although I did find the film's blatant transphobia a bit icky as it didn't sit well with me.Despite that, the film is undeniably worth checking for two things: its production value and the cast. The film looks very impressive, with Pao Orendain's slick camera work brilliantly capturing Marielle Hizon's highly detailed production design. You know they really spent time and money just by looking at those highly detailed set pieces and costumes, from that town church made from scratch to the period accurate wardrobe. It's only the CGI effects that looks pretty inconsistent. The film's sound design, courtesy of Immanuel Verona and Nerrina Salim, also gives the film a more immersive experience.On top of this, the performances of the cast are worth every peso. Gloria Diaz is committed from start to finish with her character as Doña Facunda, while Janella Salvador and Elisse Joson are both effective as Agnes and Felicity. JC Santos occasionally steals the show with his compelling turn as Brother Lucas, who helps Jonathan investigate his family's dark history. But it is Piolo Pascual who keeps the entire show running as he plays four different characters in the movie. His unforgettable performance here as Juan Severino Mallari, the latter's descendants Johnrey and Jonathan, and even an evil version of St. Bartholomew is definitely for the ages.It's not exactly scary, as it spends most of its time with jump scares that, while effective, are all forgotten eventually. It's no surprise that this one's pretty divisive, as your appreciation with the film will depend on how far you can take all of its silliness. But while it does fall short of its very high aspirations, this ridiculously bonkers and incredibly ambitious time warping horror mash-up is still worth every buck, thanks to its top-notch production value and its impressive cast, led by Piolo Pascual.

Was expecting a lot from this. I first heard of Fr. Severino Mallari in a true crime podcast and he was hailed as the first and only serial killer in the Philippines. I was just expecting a true biopic of Fr. Mallari and know his motivations for killing several people. I was not expecting some supernatural and time travel sh*t. JC Santos and Piolo Pascual are really good in this film, though.

The film weaves an intricate horror lore out of the flimsiest of historical material, as not much else is really known about the real-life serial killer Juan Severino Mallari. Exploring the motivations behind his murders, the movie spins an engaging tale of obsession, time travel, and blind filial duty that's made even richer with excellent use of Pinoy folklore, superstition, and Catholicism. The scoring and camerawork were excellent. The writing seemed heavy-handed at times, but the cast's stellar performances - particularly JC Santos' - more than make up for this!

god-awful (pun intended) CGI aside, this film could have been better with a lesser theatrical script. the lines exposed so much of the character and the story without leaving room for mystery. about 20 minutes in I was already cringing in my seat – the script was just all over the place.the jumpscares got old quick, musical scoring was almost fine but it just gravitated between being loud and sudden to force tension into the scene. there were plenty of "duh" moments, too. at many points it felt like a play where the actor had to voice out his (very obvious) realizations. this film could really do with SUBTLETY – it's horror, let the people fear the unknown. don't lay everything out that quickly.acting-wise, I was relieved to see JC Santos take on a character that deviated from the usual sad lover boy trope – it's about damn time. Piolo was great, Janella looked promising (the script really botched her potential lol I mean what the fuck was that ending???), Elisse was also alright.costume and makeup were phenomenal, though. the plot alone (or the main actor alone) is enough to draw a lot of people in, but what i really liked about this particular story is how it alluded to a particular saint – it's a strong artistic choice to make that story up for this film. i just wish the script delivered both more and less to make all of it come full circle. parang ang daming gustong mangyari ng writer (time travel, true crime solving, witchcraft/black magic, religious cult, filipino mythology, demonic possession...etc.). isa-isa lang, lol.

Ika nga ni Gojo Satoru, "Love is truly the most twisted curse of all."Watched this movie's 6:00 PM screening at SM City Cebu, and I was surprised at how long the ticketing line still is there. It's a pain to wait to buy a ticket, of course, but it just made me more excited to watch Mallari.First and foremost, I love horror movies. Literally one of my favorite genres ever. I am also one of those horror fans who have little tolerance for jump scares; it would scare me at first, but it'd eventually irritate me especially when overdone. This film could have scrapped some of those, since the way most scenes are shot already got the atmosphere to give you the creeps. The abundance of jump scares comes off like the film's underestimating the audience's perception of fear, and that aspect would have made me give this 2.5/5 stars.But the story it's trying to tell surely won me over, hence the 3 stars. Though the social commentary in the film is weaker and there are lapses in the fiction part of the narrative, it succeeds to tell how love is the main predictor for the curse that plagues the Mallari bloodline. It also successfully tells how in some cases, history is truly repeated if ignored. I see why Piolo Pascual was also others' bet for Best Actor, his acting really made the 3 main characters shine in their own ways (and his role as Fr. Pedro Pelaez in Gomburza is noteworthy too by the way, Papa P FATHERED). Out of the 3 stories presented, my favorite definitely has to be Johnrey's. Too bad that for me, his storyline doesn't seem as fleshed out as Severino's or Jonathan's, as he is the "tragic hero" of the movie.In spite of the film's blatant flaws, it's still a movie that deserves all the hype and the awards they've received from the Gabi Ng Parangal. Do see it in cinemas before MMFF 2023 closes, it's nice to scream with other people in the cinema!

"Sometimes, love is a curse and there's nothing else in the world that can break it."Got to watched this film in an almost jampacked cinema and all I can say that it is a good balance between suspense and horror. Well, for me, it brought me back to the old horror films filled with the typical jumpscares thag you'll still get surprised but it also gives you this suspense feeling like sitting at the edge of your chair wondering what could be the next thing that will happen in the movie.The transitions between the three eras were smooth that it was a little bit confusing at first glance but I loved how it incorporates the three timelines on a single important event of the whole story and presents you each on how they are intersected at that moment. It was definitely good on how they are able to play around the plot and not spill the whole thing on one go. I loved that portion and Piolo Pascual's acting is the best I've seen and maybe this is his best movie on his entire career. From the visual, to the acting, to the pronounciations that make the timelines distinct on their own helps very well on distinguishing the three different timelines of Severino, Johnrey and Jonathan. I would also love to add some praise for JC Santos. Being a theatre kid gains you so much and we've seen it through his performance.Just two things I did not love as much.1) The Manananggal Scene (did not resonated as much or did not do anything for the plot, I guess? And a little too corny for the well produced film)2) The Ending (I am looking for more information on how things end up like that. Like from JC's character to Janella's "memory" of who she is now after what Piolo did)But despite these things, I found Mallari to be a good film and despite not being a fan of horror films, this is one of those horror films at the top my list (as it was a good horro movie and because I can still sleep st night after watching this)

It was only in the third quarter of the film where it became interesting. The conclusion was also weak.Looking for the three video reels for a couple of days in a small house to solve a mystery was ridiculously stupid. The screenplay was not very good most especially in the wedding proposal scene; and the delivery of lines were bad. There was barely modulation in line delivery. It contains many cheap and ineffective jumpscares although two of them were remarkable (i.e, hospital scene in the beginning and ghost hunting with the children). The horror elements in the film was also full of cliché.Over-all, it has a nice premise which could have been actualized through good direction.

Sa pagpanood ko ng 'Mallari,' hindi ko maitatangging napabilib ako sa kagandahan ng pelikula. Ang ganda ng pagkakagawa at ang twist sa kwento ay talaga namang kakaiba. Isa itong obra na nagpapatunay na may talento ang direktor na ito sa pagbuo ng kakaibang karanasan para sa manonood.Ngunit, napansin ko rin na parang may allergy ang direktor sa mga happy ending sa mga pelikula sa ngayon. Sa kabila ng ganda ng cinematography at ang kahusayan ng pagganap ni Piolo at ng buong cast, hindi maikakaila na tila iniiwasan ng pelikula ang pangwakas na may saya.Ang mga pangyayari sa pelikula ay hindi lamang maganda sa mata kundi kakaiba rin. Ang mga eksena ay nadama ko sa bawat angulo, at ang husay ng mga aktor, lalo na si Piolo at ang buong cast, ay nagbibigay-buhay sa karakter.Sa kabuuan, isang kahanga-hangang pelikula ang 'Mallari,' bagamat may konting bahid ng lungkot sa pagtatapos nito. Subalit, sa kabila nito, hindi maitatangging ang ganda at husay nito ay nagbibigay ng marka sa industriya ng pelikulang Pilipino.Btw, ang sakit sa ulo na pure tagalog ang ginamit ko sa pag-komento haha!

I didn't expect much from this movie as I'd been hearing a LOT of negative reviews. I went in blind, and I happened to enjoy it!It was a horror movie that made sense (if you're open to peculiar storylines, of course). The first half was confusing and wonky, but the latter half at least made up for it by tying up the initially disconnected events together in a way that stimulated the audience's minds. Plot twists were revealed in this way when I didn't think there was anything more to expect. The movie was intentionally NOT subtle about the true culprit's identity because there were MORE IMPORTANT twists. Some bits of dialogue, especially in the romantic scenes, were cringe-inducing and unnatural. Even Janella's and Piolo's decent acting couldn't make it bearable. The insertion of key story elements (e.g., time traveling) could have been better with a less cheesy dialogue. Speaking of acting, JC Santos DESERVES the Best Supporting Actor Award. Piolo's acting was the weakest despite portraying the MAIN character; he was outshined by the supporting actors. There were multiple layers to the story that influenced the characters' complexity. Wikipedia would tell us that Fr. Juan Severino Mallari killed 57 people as a "cure" for his mother's sickness, which he deemed cursed. But the movie went all out: There was MORE to show within 2 hours. I loved the ending. Life's true horror did not come from stories about ghosts but from a person's adamance in committing mistakes that would negatively impact the people around them.
