+:- plot-wise, it's def a richer, more nuanced, and more thought-out narrative compared to most PH horror na super predictable na ng plot twists + generic elements. i like what it tried to do with 3 diff time periods though ofc the time traveling/astral projecting was a stretch and maybe a tad too ambitious writing-wise. still a good effort tho- characters: all played well. i liked the juxtaposition between severino - a serial killer who didn't enjoy it and didn't actually WANT to be it - and lucas who DID enjoy being a copycat killer and WANTED to do it. jc santos deserved his best supporting actor award. - technical elements: production design goes so hard esp knowing they built some of the key parts of the setting. the score was also particularly good tho maybe im just biased for church/choral elements-:- im not a big fan of origin stories of "female monsters" when the presented origin is so male-centric. sure, in this case it was women who set upon the curse that started the monster - but why? just for someone else to do their bidding? i wish they showed more of the alarcons and why they did what they did. if the motivation is supposed to be wrath at the injustice done against ppl like them, then i wish they leaned into that more, kulang lang ng detail pa for that- mallari stopped being scary the moment it was revealed that his mom saw smth nieves led her to watch. dun palang i already knew severino would only be forced to kill, not that he wanted to himself. im not a fan of this either lol he'd be a much more sinister character if HE was the fanatic and saw himself as san bartolome on his own accord BUT i know that's not the point of the story so sige na nga- why naman di na lang niya niligtas si agnes eh doktor din naman si jonathan ... tapos pampanga yan in present time beh dami dami nang ospital tas may kotse rin naman si agnes mabilis kayo makakarating dun medyo nkklk- AND SPEAKING OF THE HOSPITAL: in the first scene na pinakitang nasa hospital bed si agnes, ang sabi ng nurse "end stage na po siya" so akala ko naman cancer or some life-threatening disease. ngayon pala stab wound amp pano yon end stage nakapagsalita pa nga and all ewan ko ba- and the ending ... i get it they needed a shot of jonathan like that, but i wish it was even more tragic. filipino writing is sometimes so hooked on expositional writing but sometimes that gets too annoying to listen to and to act out. i wish they didn't show agnes eating the chick. ok na sana that they showed jonathan smiling while holding up johnrey's head and the chick is coming out of its mouth - and then cut na agad to the mallari house and the secret room, where agnes is chained and jonathan is "lovingly" feeding her entrails while she looks like she'd rather be dead after killing him IDK. personally didnt feel like all that dialogue was necessary in the end but ok gets pa rin namanoverall tho, i hope this film encourages more horror filmmakers to take on compelling stories! our culture is SOOO rich for this literally andaming pwedeng material for horror and im so glad to see i can look forward to more daring horror films like this now in the PH

Mallari is a horror-thriller film based on the Philippines' first recorded serial killer hailing from Pampanga. With this in mind, the film attempts to take us on a wild ride of discovery, boldly mixing genres that, while commendable, more often than not gets derailed into different directions. MAZES AND DAZESFirstly, it's admirable how the story attempts to give Filipino audiences something different. It marries the familiar Philippine folklore horror elements with sci-fi and mystery thriller with dashes of history, comedy, and even family drama. The story unfolds with a non-linear structure, too, which makes it interesting.The issues lay with this very idea that it wanted to do so much with so little time. The first half of the film lays all of the mystery, while the second half picks up the pace and fully turns into a horror story.Jamming too many elements somehow took away from what could have been great points in the story if only they leaned more into them and chose: did it want to be more of a historical horror or a mystery thriller slasher cult modern classic?BRIGHT AND DULL SPOTSPiolo Pascual playing multiple roles across generations would've been a great feat for an actor of his caliber. But somehow, something was missing in his portrayal that left me wanting more. His characters felt like they were the same people, save for two distinct moments in the chapel and in the hospital towards the end.Undeniable standouts were JC Santos and Gloria Diaz. They were spectacular and generous in their supporting roles and stole scenes whenever they came up beside Pascual. They were delightful to watch. OVERALLDespite its major flaws, I like how everything was wrapped up. All of the mysteries and questions set up were resolved and given their end, no loose ends (which could've easily been the case given its ambition and scope).Mallari is an example of what happens when you allow filmmakers to be adventurous and bold in their ideas. It can lead to a bumpy and crazy, yet fun and adventurous ride.
a pretty solid movie! definitely not perfect but has the potential to kickstart a new age for filipino horror movies. 7.5/10!

watching this in the cinemas was definitely a fun experience especially when the audience (mostly strangers) also insert funny commentaries here and there that you can’t help but laugh at. the people behind our backs were especially funny i couldn’t help but to acknowledge how that elevated my experience. as for the movie itself…. first, i would like to point out how much i loooooove the musical scoring. i have no complaints about that. i also liked the acting especially jc santos like woah okay best supporting actor indeed! and also liked the fact that janella salvador is here like woah everyone’s eye candy is piolo pascual but mine is janella so there’s room for everybody! that said, what i didn’t like about the movie is how they didn’t explore much about the first filipino serial killer aspect more. i went in expecting that they would explore the story of the murders itself, the aftermath, the consequences, and how the priest was discovered as the murderer but i guess that’s on me for expecting something like that, something nbc hannibal-like? honestly, i just really wished they focused more on the murders since it is a mystery/thriller aspect in itself but i guess mallari wasn’t going for that. like hello, the first documented serial killer of the philippines was a catholic priest and that in itself is intriguing as a predominantly catholic country. anyway, i did like the time traveling aspect to explore the narrative but at the same time i feel like it wasn’t utilized well enough to really wrap up the story… but props to piolo pascual for pulling off the roles well.

Grabe yung Mallari! Deserve yung nominations at lahat ng awards nung Gabi ng Parangal. Grabe yung utak ni Enrico Santos at Derrick Cabrido for creating such masterpiece. It is Piolo versus Piolo versus Piolo! He once again proved na he’s not just a pretty face. Talagang lumaban si JC Santos literally and figuratively at pasabog naman po si Gloria Diaz.Kung ako magdedecide, bibigyan ko na lang sila ng tig-iisang BALUT para tumigil silang lahat.  YUN NA! out of 5

I can't remember the last time I really enjoyed a Filipino horror film. MALLARI is both gothic and cerebral---- my kind of horror film. This is brilliant filmmaking. Piolo serving us an acting masterclass.Much of the criticism about MALLARI is the abundance of jump scares, and I agree that they are quite tiring after a certain time. MALLARI works best during its moments of quiet dread: two scenes in particular (without giving much away) are my favorite.ONE, the film showing featuring some unwelcome guests.TWO, that Baile scene. Pao Orendain's camerawork is dizzying, maddening, which like the storytelling, is taking all of us for a spin.

MMFF 2023 A lot was expected since Warner Bros. co-produced it. To be honest, the story has lots of potential. There are a lot of cringey lines. The set design was mediocre. Their Music and Sound were just okay. To be fair, I had no trouble figuring out which timeline it was during the transition period. Their cinematography was simple; numerous shots were repeated frequently. I’m not a big fan of their visual effects. But i liked the color. The performance of Piolo Pascual should have been better. JC Santos deserves the Best Supporting Actor Award. Overall, not bad for a Filipino Horror Film. Sayang lang talaga ang story. Hawak na nila ang best screenplay. They could have done better.

Horror, I guess, is truly the most challenging film genre, and you feel it in the struggles of PH cinema. Often, in our horror films, the story is either unclear or unintentionally turns into comedy due to poor visual effects. In this film, I don't quite get why the fear factor feels forced. There are numerous jumpscares that seem repetitive and not very surprising.Perhaps the film could still deliver (or even be better) if the horror vibes weren't forced (especially the manananggal scene, it might have been better off excluded). But it's still a 4-star rating from me because I did enjoy watching it. It gives off similar vibes to Seklusyon since both are horror and revolve around religion, making it inevitable to compare the two.There are few local horror films with a good screenplay, and this is one of those succeeding in that aspect. The disturbing ending was exactly what I wanted to spark discussions and curiosity about the life of Father Severino Mallari. Kudos to the filmmakers for the smooth transitions between scenes, and you genuinely feel the thrill.The score was superb (the bayle scene was chef's kiss), but there were times when the sound effects are annoying because it's too loud and hurts the ears. The editing still needs more improvement. The visual effects are far from perfect, but they're already good and a significant improvement compared to other local films, especially in the horror genre. What truly stood out here is the phenomenal acting of Piolo Pascual, with three characters portrayed, and JC Santos, who is truly deserving of his Best Supporting Actor award (they nailed it in their last scene together). I believe Piolo Pascual is the Brad Pitt of the Philippines because he never seems to age.There are many loopholes and points for improvement, but the film's concept is indeed impressive, and in some ways, it probably delivered the intended message to viewers. I'm happy because I see this as a launching pad for the progress of local horror films, and the trajectory is only heading upwards.

A bit messy but ambitious in scale Filipino movie.This film is at its best whenever it stays grounded to its plot—which is a nice concept and disturbing story to begin with. However, there were lots of unnecessary jumpscares and it leaned little too much on being a typical horror which was a distraction from its good narrative and pacing. I think this would actually be better if it focused on being a crime thriller rather than a jumpscare horror but keeping the nice blend of crime, horror, historical, time-travel, fantasy and filipino folklore themes that made this gripping and worth the while.

#Mallari is the jump scare of the year! This is another scary movie that's worth seeing. Its story, its riddles, its terror, and all of its aesthetically pleasing eras are cohesive. I appreciate how they told the plot without losing sight of the fact that you are still seeing a masterful horror movie. I was a little lost in the present day, but the plot's shifting texture gave the stories, folklore, and social constructs more substance. It’s easy to follow despite moving around inti three periods because its visuals made sure they compliment, and at the same time contradict each other.Piolo Pascual, your Best Actor award is in the bag, with Gloria Diaz and JC Santos are strong candidates for acting noms. Quite lengthy, but it lets you take a break from thrilling scenes. Again, slow clap for the artwork and visual effects. #MMFF2023

Rather than tell a straightforward slasher/police procedural story like in most serial killer-centric films, Mallari opts for a unique approach: focusing on a historic Filipino figure. Oh and time travel as plot device. The film certainly has great ingredients. The combined acting prowess of Piolo Pascual, JC Santos, and Ms. Gloria Diaz. The Enrico Santos-penned screenplay that combines Gothic atmospheres, Catholic traditions, (almost) Lovecraftian ancient evils, love and madness, and the dance between Christianity and violence. The visuals refreshingly don't look made for TV which, in my perspective, dominates Filipino visual media today. Y'know the overly lit backgrounds. Or sickening coloring. Sadly though, Mallari is overdone but not in the fun, unique way. It falls into the usual trappings of conventional big-budget films these days (it is a Warner Brothers affair). The jumpscares that define much of this film's genre are too one-note. A character enters a room and then there's a figure, either behind or in front, which slowly turns around, revealing black eyes, decaying skin, and mouth wide open. Dramatic score in the background to accentuate the fear. Watching it alone in a dark room can make those scenes scary, sure. But would it kill the filmmakers to create sequences that haunt, not merely surprise? Suspenseful equences that paralyze you for a minute, instead of five seconds of jumpscare? The score too, good Lord, would it kill to have silence? Let the dread creep in. Build on the minutes-long discomfort. I want to hear my own heart beating not let some loud Gregorian chant to do all the emotional carrying.
final verdict: pogi ang 3 generations ng piolo

Welcome back, Philippine Horror Cinema! 1) The sequencing format is superb. Despite having three different timelines, it did not lead to confusion or a "wtf is happening" moment. The timelines were executed really well. 2) The amount of jumpscares, or even just the scary parts, is commendable. This is what horror movies should look like. 3) Piolo Pascual's Performance is really commendable! He was able to differentiate between each character he was portraying. 4) Setting / Production is great. Timelines were differentiated and can be easily identified. Areas to Improve:- Played too safe with the gore, hence it was something we don't really mind. The horror elements are enough. - 2 murders in the modern day could not justify the "serial killings", would be great if there were at least one or two more. - I, personally, did not like Janella's fate. Could've been better.

I didn't like how it relied on useless jump scares in the first half as it really goes to unsettling territories in its second half. The pacing overall feels very clunky and the characters are stiff and almost dumb at some parts. A frustrating missed opportunity.

janella salvador willing ko tanggapin yang sisiw na yan para sayook slightly srs review incoming !!(editing aspect) i cant believe the bad gma-inspired cgi still passes on even on the big screen. imposible talaga na kulang o limited ang mga mahuhusay na cgi artists sa ph. i read that most local tv shows scrimp on their sfx editors to allocate their funds to other needs or are generally on a tight budget but seriously hanggang dito ba naman? huhu sayang kasi its these little repetitive things that hinder the quality. in some scenes, imo mas maganda kung dinaan nlang nila sa sfx na makeup hindi cgi. to add sa editing nito, the transitions please yes to experimenting & gaining inspiration from creative transitions but please not in your entries for an anticipated film festival, and im not just talking about this movie but in the other entries as well. i really would have settled with a simple cut transition or a basic fade in/out huhu(plot aspect + cinematog + misc) idk i liked their twist to the og story of ph's first serial killer. it strayed from ur normal historical piece such as gomburza, heneral luna, etc. i really liked how there were scenes u would dismiss at the start and by the end, its so satisfying to revisit those scenes but with all the pieces finally falling into place. also hindi sila bobo ?? except sa dulo cguro pero di tanga tanga mga desisyon nila like the typical horror movie. just a bit weird with the out of place comedy (still enjoyable tho) tsaka ewan may moments na mapapa tanong ka lang kung controversial ba toh o oa lang ba ako... anw my last criticism would be on the jumpscares. again please we can do better than this!! ive seen better jumpscares and build ups than this in old horror films na napapanood ko sa cinemaone channel fr. okei tapos na ang pagdada ko & i, thank u

A decent one with intriguing concepts and elements that aren't prevalent in other horror-thriller movies. Some jump scares shouldn't be included, imo. The creepy scoring is more than enough to fit the screenplay; the pacing is a bit messy and could be improved, but the last stretch swiftly sums up how good the plot line is. Piolo's portrayal definitely showed the differences between the three generations; I have to commend how it was depicted. JC Santos' performance was top-notch; no wonder he won as the best supporting actor for this filmfest.I'm also impressed by how it includes Filipino folklore and mythology, how Christianity has severely influenced us all up until now, and the way they show how religion affects one's overall character.

My first film for 2024 and I would say I fairly had fun. I definitely did not expect that going into this film, although eventually I enjoyed the plot as it went on. The film looks good. Both in terms of production design and cinematography. The film sounds good, both in terms of sound design and scoring. The film also manages to weave together the three narratives of three generations of the Mallari clan very well. I just wish that the narrative themselves were fleshed out and developed well. It felt like the film is trying to say too much that it ended up not saying anything at all. However, I do think that the film's epilogue is easily its greatest strength. Particularly, the hospital scene. The way it was shot, the way it was scored, the performances truly hooked me in that moment. I wish there were more moments like that in the film, but what we got were CGI-elongated faces of dead people followed by sudden hitting of notes in an attempt to produce scares out of the audience.

82/100 - Satisfactory (83-82)Negatives:-The dialogues were too sloppy. The film has three time frames and it didn't manage to be consistent throughout. The plot was oversaturated with great ideas with no sufficient developments.-With a lot of characters and plotlines to chew under a 2hr runtime, I find the some sequences abnormally fast-paced.-I just don't buy the time travel thing, it's nonsense.Positives:-Piolo giving another great performance as expected. The standout for me was definitely JC; I view him as the Barry Keoghan of PH.-The horror elements were definitely effective, the theater audience really elevated the experience. -Although it felt rushed, the film managed to tie together the different plots of the different timeframes properly.
Some scenes of the movie caught me off guard but the reason why I rate this 4.5 is because the musical scores instead of the story of the movie XD

A solid attempt at Filipino magical realism. Do not expect a historical horror film. The plot may diverge and expand needlessly but the core of the film is strong in its main character and thesis. This will be my go-to film recommendation for any foreigner or diasporic Filipino looking to learn about Filipino culture: religion and spirituality, community justice, generational trauma, familial dependency, colonial and post-colonial society, and folklore.

I watched Mallari without knowing anything, except the fact that the movie has its historical basis and majority of the people in my internet sphere said that it was good. I did not expect to come out of the cinema witnessing a movie which is basically an amalgamation of multiple genres.Mallari's strengths were its phenomenal acting from a star-studded cast, its great cinematography, and its pacing is okay.Mallari's weaknesses were its all over-the- place writing and personally, I think, the movie could've done better and not spoonfeed everything to the viewers and let them think for themselves. Also, it had tons of ineffective jumpscares that do not contribute anything to the plot and for some scenes, the scoring was kind of jarring and felt in-your-face.Overall, I enjoyed watching Mallari even though it's somewhat predictable. Also, we all could've saved two hours of our lives if only someone handed Jonathan a balut in the first place. Metro Manila Film Festival 2023 @ SM Megamall
Bat naging si kokey nanay ni mallari

-;        &  Noong 1800's, ang lalawigan ng Magalang, Pampanga ay saksi sa isang hanay ng mga pagpatay sa loob ng isang dekada. Isang tanyag na kura paroko na nagngangalang Juan Severino Mallari ang pinaghihinalaang pumatay sa humigit kumulang 57 katao.Sa pelikulang ito ni Direk Derick Cabrido, hindi lamang niya tinutukan ang buhay ni Father Severino bilang kauna-unahang serial killer sa Pilipinas, ito rin ay nagbibigay ng makabuluhang mensahe tungkol sa pag-ibig, bagamat isang nakakakilabot na representasyon ng pag-ibig, habang nilalakbay ang mga masalimuot na landas ng pagmamahal, kahit pa ito ay may kaakbay na panganib. Talagang hindi matatawaran ang pagganap ng isa sa pinakakilalang aktor sa bansa na si Piolo Pascual. Ibang "Papa P" ang makikita sa pelikulang ito. Iba't ibang pagkatao, iba't ibang emosyon, at iba't ibang kwento. Hindi madali ang gumanap ng tatlong persona kaya kahanga-hanga ang ipinamalas ng aktor. Isa sa gusto kong karakter na ginampanan niya ay si Father Severino Mallari. Nabigyan nya ng hustisya ang karakter na ito, makikita mo sa mga mata niya kung anong emosyon ang nais niyang ipahatid sa mga manonood. Takot, galit, at pagmamahal, walang duda, nakilala siya dahil sa kanyang angking galing. Gaya ni Piolo, ipinamalas rin ni JC Santos ang kanyang galing sa pag-arte na gumanap bilang Lucas. Isa siya sa pinakanagdala ng pelikula, kaya naman hindi nakakapagtaka na sya ang napiling bigyan ng parangal ng MMFF bilang Best Supporting Actor ngayong taon.Kakaiba ang atake na bitbit ng “Mallari” dahil hindi lamang nakasentro sa horror ang pelikula ngunit sumasaklaw din ito sa iba't ibang genre tulad ng thriller, sci-fi, folklore, kasaysayan, romance, at family drama. Nakakamangha na napagsama-sama ito sa iisang pelikula. Mahusay nitong inilarawan ang kontradiksyon ng pag-ibig bilang isang biyaya at sumpa. Katulad ng sinabi sa pelikula “Ang isang tao ay kabuuan ng kaniyang mga desisyon, minamahal, at mga pagkakamali," gaano nga ba kalalim ang kaya nating isugal para sa pag-ibig?

Presenting the Piolo Pascual Multiverse of Madness. Charot.Mallari commits to taking advantage of the Filipino lore to create a piece that can be exciting despite going all over the place for perhaps half of the time. The film wanted to be many different things all at once and truly attempted to connect the dots but not without shortcomings. There are justifiable parts, then there are “what the hell is going on” ones.Regardless of the mishaps, such as the lack of cinematic fluidity and overpowering score, Mallari is an entertaining experience - thanks to Piolo Pascual’s constant reinvention as an actor. I personally appreciated the homage to our long history of integrating elements of religion, mythology, and superstitions that has been effective as early as the Spanish Colonial Period in the Philippines.

The Philippine Horror Movie scene has had a very interesting existence, to say the least. Our culture is ripe with legends and fables about supernatural beings committing atrocities, and many variations of these tales have made their way to the silver screen - whether that be a refrigerator eating an unwelcome houseguest, or centuries-old entities luring influencers to a “collab” to harvest their fresh flesh and blood. Sometimes, we get tales of a feminine spectre haunting a commonly-used thoroughfare in Quezon City, and sometimes we’ll get a tale about the horrors that have befallen families simply because they’ve set wedding dates so close to each other. One horror trope, which has not been explored much in Filipino cinema, is that of the serial killer slasher film. One film dares to go deeper into that sub-genre, an attempt that has elicited much anticipation and hype. The question is, does the film live up to said hype?Full review here: www.cinegeekspod.com/post/mallari-movie-review

Not sure what I was expecting, but this was not it. Haha. Look, the film was visually stunning from the cinematography, camera work, and transitions. I also didn’t mind the overbearing score and the acting was fine. I just wished the movie went on a different direction than this because the fantastical element - including the time travel, agawang sisiw, etc - while interesting, to some extent, felt too absurd and unnecessarily convoluted especially since this was based on a true story. The twists were frustratingly predictable and some of the jumpscares felt too heavy handed. I wanted something more grounded and what I got was a gorgeous looking Pinoy horror film that gave me nothing other than a bunch of eye rolls and confused look. Haha.

Jump scare galore. Mallari is a disappointing horror film filled with contrived jump scares. It's overly ambitious with a really thin time travelling plot and heavy handed screenplay that tried to tie all three generations but failed to do so. Should've focused on "first serial killer" instead of it being a fantasy because the tragedy in all of it felt wasted. This really felt like a passion project of a folklore/ghost enthusiast with so much ideas in their mind. Really felt like it's inspired by Ricky Lee's Amapola but just all over the place. Performances are also meh while the saving grace of this film is in its visuals and camera movement, and some of the set design is pretty impressive.

?!?!.Andami kong pwede masabi kasi nainis ako of how a lot of things didn’t work because of how forced they could feel but I also loved how technical the writing and even the editing was in having to pull off three different generations merging them as one story despite some generic dialogues with bits of random humor. But in the end, it felt like everything got too much and a lot of things became unnecessary already.Piolo and JC both shined in the film and delivered haunting performances. The production also made a hell of a film despite how the finished product can be divisive to a lot of people.

The concept of exploring the Philippines' only recorded serial killer was an excellent idea, but the execution was blown out of proportion. There was so much happening and too many themes were being introduced. While the intention was there, it was just too ambitious for its own good. Also, the jump-scare-galore type of horror made it less and less "scary" nearing the end.On the other hand, the inclusion of Philippine lore, the eerie sound design & score, and excellent acting (especially JC Santos) were the film's redeeming factors. Overall, it wasn't a bad film through and through, but it could have been better.6/10

The concept of time travel in storytelling is a nice approach. It was well presented how the 3 different generations of Mallari were portrayed, but it also showcased that—even now and then, there’s a curse that has been happening in our country (in the context of societal injustices). “Ang isang tao ay kabuuan ng kanyang mga desisyon… minamahal… at mga pagkakamali.”The Love lies at the core of all three varieties of Mallari. Two are driven by love for their spouses, and one is out of love for the mother. However, Jonathan and Juan Severino both have the trait of sacrificing others in order to save their loved ones. Johnray, however, gives his life to save everyone, even his loved ones. It all leads me to the question: to what extents are we willing to go for the sake of love?For the production, when it comes to horror, it’s either you go big or go home. This means that to be able to justify the concept of a horror film, you will need to exert a lot of effort in executing it, from cinematography, lights, sound design, production design, and wardrobe & prosthetics. I applaud the sound design that carried the whole jump scare, the lights that signified each scenery, the PD, wardrobe, & hmu, who emphasized the time frame, symbolism, and their story as a character.Though there are some unnecessary parts and certain areas that could use of improvement, but overall, I applaud how well they have shown the history, culture, and Filipino myths in this film. The messages they unfold about societal issues, needs to be recognized more; hence, they tackle serious issues such as the injustice killing which represents the EJK, and how the lgbtq community is still considered as part of the “salot ng lipunan”, and many more, that are still happening today.

ang ganda sana. so many interesting elements, derived from such an interesting story, but it was too ambitious. merong subplots that throw you off the main plot. hindi natahi nang maayos yung scenes in a way that makes the story clear; naging nakakalito lang. + too many jumpscares that didn't add anything to the plot. but i still appreciated a lot of things in the film. ang ganda ng production, ang galing ng performances (pleasantly surprised by jc santos the most). may scenes na nagustuhan ko talaga. and the themes, although too many at once, were still intriguing. i really wish we got to focus on just one.most of my complaints i've already discussed with friends right after the movie. ang paulit-ulit na term na ginamit namin: sayang.

Piolo Multiverse The story was confusing at first since hindi ko pa ma-connect pero at the end, everything made sense. Medyo na-off lang sa bandang dulo na scene (iykyk). The jumpscares are predictable for me pero nagulat pa rin ako. haha. The musical scoring really elevated the entire film (yup, it was that great). Color grading and the shots felt like an international film. Overall, I love how they incorporate Philippine mythology and lore into this film and kudos to Piolo Pascual for acting three different characters and made them distinctive as well as JC’s excellent acting skills (deserve ang best supporting actor).

Making the Philippine’s first recorded serial killer a side character rather than the main lead was a miss. There’s so much lore and history around the character just for it to be overshadowed by present time’s Mallari and his spiral. If the movie was solely about the priest, it would’ve been a fucking hit, but I admire the unique take on astral projection and time traveling.While I applaud Piolo Pascual’s talent in portraying three different characters, I can’t help but think if there would’ve been a better way to introduce these characters and their stories. The constant flashbacks and sudden time jumps were bordering on overkill, I personally would’ve enjoyed if the movie was sectioned into three parts instead to have a consistent story line because trying to decipher each time period’s plot made the movie feel longer than it actually was. Reading the wikipedia plot was more entertaining.Also, what the hell is this movie’s lightning problem? A majority of the jump scares are either the killer or ghosts in the background but I wouldn’t know because I couldn’t see shit. Speaking of jump scares, Philippine cinema needs to find new ways of scaring its viewers rather than the typical ~scary image~ with loud music. I admit, some of it worked, but the tension in teasing a potential jump scare is more memorable than a lousy 5 second scare imo. Or maybe I’m just used to the American horror movie industry and the likes of Blumhouse or A24.To cut it sweet, the parts I liked: the hospital scene at the end being shown in the beginning, each Mallari’s origins in how all three ended up being in one room at the same time shown throughout the movie, Janella Salvador, the manananggal reveal, generational Alarcon vs Mallari, Piolo Pascual’s acting, and the overall filmography of it all.Would I watch it again? Mhm, probably not. Did I still enjoy seeing Piolo Pascaul and Janella Salvador on the big screen? Hell fucking yes.

Plot: No loopholes, everything was answered and nasatisfy ako until the end kasi it lets me think on what happens next pero at the same time I don’t need na kasi every part of the story is enough to keep you satisfied and kasi you already know what happens to the Mallari Family.  The storyline will flow with you and will answer all of your questions!Jump-scares: Medyo OA lang some scenes ng ibang ghosts hindi ko talaga bet haha. Para lang siyang in-add out of nowhere sa script to make it “scarier” since plain nga lang talaga ang flow pag Serial Killers ang story. They added that “oomph” badly pero gets naman na pinoy medyo need ng OA sa life char. When you rewind the clips siguro di talaga nakakatakot yung faces, nakakagulat lang pero “eh” ang makeup, for me, + may OA din na SFX during jumpscares na di ko nabet-an. It’s too much.Acting: hands down to Piolo Pascual for portraying 3 DIFFERENT CHARACTERS flawlessly!!! Ang galing at walang bahid/mix ng other characters na Mallari. Siguro given na din na they’re from different timelines pero kitang kita mo yung difference ng character and harmony nila together as “Mallaris”. Special mention to JC Santos!! Napakaganda ng execution niya with his character! + the women in the film Janella and Elisse very strong characters indeed!Cinematography: Seamless and Experimental Since the story has 3 different timelines, it jumps from one timeline to another and super clean ng transitions. Experimental in a way na they’ve incorporated transitions to jump from one dialogue to another and from one Mallari to the next Mallari in another timeline!For the color grading, *chef’s kiss* it speaks for itself and bawat history ng family nila seamless ang colors. All in all, ganda ng execution!Camera Work:  super love it di ko na explain watch niyo nalang very visible yung ganda ng camera work nila!!Production Design: THE BEST. Bawat details sa set ng timelines kuhang kuha!! It feels so alive na parang nangyari talaga siya in real life.Slasher Factor: At the end of the day, it’s a story about a Serial Killer, medyo nakulangan lang ako sa Serial Killer factor niya. With the slashing scenes, nabitin ako! Kulang sa patayan! Medyo heavily kasi nag focus yung story sa Filipino Theme na may added witchcraft, superstitions, folklore. Which is gets ko kasi it’s a Filipino Serial Killer it’s bound to be incorporated with Filipino themes. With the added themes, it’s too chaotic, in somewhat a good way? Hahaha. Though sana dinagdagan pa nila yung slashing and killings kasi bitin! For the gore, pwede na ilaban. AdditionalSince this is Fiction, some scenes are familiar sa other Horror/Thriller Films that I’ve watched kaya parang magegets mo na din yung scene or mahahalata mo na influenced siya with a certain film.Films like Mallari: Sinister, Insidious, Lights Out Sucker for history and true crime!!

MALLARI, MMFF2023: Based on Filipino Catholic priest Juan Severino Mallari (1785–1840), the first documented serial killer from the Philippines; Director Roderick Cabrido and writer Enrico Santos deliver a story that takes the premise of Mallari's serial killing and uses it as backstory to advance the horror elements of the film's three-timeline, three-Piolo Pascual act. Personally, I might be in the minority who thinks that, with reports of Mallari showing signs of mental instability around the same time of his killing spree, the film would have worked better as a psychological thriller, sans the folk horror aspect. The filmmakers seemingly took advantage of the paucity of verifiable records about the man's life — so much that the liberties they took just screams 'WOW'. Mallari, in its sheer unapologetic glory, is a very interesting mess. As an alchemy of historical thriller and folk horror, at times it becomes too tiring, that audiences can be forgiven for expecting scares before they even appear onscreen. This marriage ultimately combusts in the end, leaving only one of the two as the last genre standing.And for that, flaws and all, I feel Mallari deserves a closer look for its guts to prioritize jump scares to frighten its audiences shitless; even if by doing so, it compromises history — and the last ounces of accuracy remaining — by putting it on the back burner.

Horror film na may kuwento at hindi jump-scares lang ang puhunan.Bago ang konsepto ng pelikula. Inspired ito sa totoong kuwento ni Juan Severino Mallari na hinaluan ng fiction. Simula pa lang ay may mga panggulat na. Mangangapa ka nga lang at malilito sa dami ng nangyayari. Pabalik-balik kasi sa timeline ng tatlong Mallari. Duda na nga ako nong kalagitnaan kung kaya ba nilang pagtagpi-tagpiin ang lahat ng bahagi ng walang sabit o plot hole.Sigawan ang mga tao sa sinehan lalo sa habulang eksena sa dulo. Kaya masasabi ko talagang effective sa pananakot ang pelikula. Marami ring plot twist na dapat abangan. May mangilan-ngilang plot holes nga lang at ilang rebelasyon na predictable pero hindi naman no’n maikakaila ang ganda ng pelikula.Sa huli’y natahi naman ng maayos ang bawat piraso. Gusto-gusto ko ang ending. Hindi ko ito inaasahan. Nakakagulat! Lalo akong humanga sa galing JC dito. Deserve na deserve ang best supporting actor. Nakakakilabot naman si Gloria Diaz! Mahirap makalimutan ang karakter niya dito. Nakakatuwang makakita ng ganitong klaseng pinoy horror. Kaya naman pala natin!

Aaminin ko. May inaasahan na ako sa Mallari dahil sa mga magagandang salita na nabasa ko. Pero hindi naging sarado para hindi maging sariwa ang pagkilala ko sa pelikula.Mabilis na ipinakilala ang karakter. Hindi sila nagpahaba ng paghihintay bago mo malaman kung tungkol saan ang pelikula. Ngunit sa simula pa lang, alam mo na yung inihahanda nilang ibunyag sa dulo ng pelikula.May mga panahon napabilib ako sa paraan ng editing at pagkuha ng eksena pero hindi ito naging sapat para mailatag ng malinaw ang istorya.May iilang eksena na hindi nakatulong sa pagkukwento bagkus nag-iwan lamang ng mga katanungan hindi na nabigyan ng kasagutan.Maayos ang ipinakita ni Piolo pero hindi ako tiyak kung ito ay kayang magpanalo sa kanya ng parangal. Pero gusto ko at nararapat siyang bigyan ng pagkilala sa maraming karakter na ginampanan niya. Kung pagbabasehan ang akting na ipinakita, SI JC Santos ang magbubuhat ng bandera sa gabi ng parangal. Mahusay at nararapat ang ipinakita niya.Medyo naguluhan lang ako sa mga manunulat kung anong kwento ba ang gusto nila para sa mga manunuod. May mga oras na mapapasigaw ka pero mas maraming oras na mapapahula ka kung ano nga ba tong pinapanuod mo sa sinehan.Ihanda ang mga tenga dahil sa sobrang lakas na tunog na ibinibigay ng pelikula. Hindi ko alam kung sa sinehan ba o sadyang ganun ang pagka-edit ng pelikula. Oo, isa itong pelikulang magpapatalon sa iyo sa kinauupuan gamit ang biswal at tunog ngunit napasobra ata ito sa lakas kumpara sa mga napanuod natin may ganitong tema.2/5 ang rating na aking ibibigay. May instensyon ang pelikula pero bigong mabuo ang kwento ng mas solido pa. Kung binabalak mong panuorin ang Mallari, baka sa streaming apps maari.

(Note: This review contains spoilers.)This is certainly one of the most bizarre films I’ve ever seen.I entered the theater expecting a retelling of Juan Severino Mallari’s story in the form of a slasher film, but ended up witnessing something completely different. My expectations were completely subverted.The film took so much creative license and put some fantasy and supernatural twists on Juan Severino Mallari’s story, which is really inventive. But while I do appreciate this creative effort, I was not quite satisfied with its outcome. As much as I want to give lots of praises to the film, I believe it has some flaws, which, unfortunately, brought down its quality.Frankly, the film was too ambitious. It tried too hard to present a complex and mind-boggling concept but ended up executing it poorly. Hence, when I left the theater, I felt that something was missing. The film didn’t turn out to be as impressive and groundbreaking as I expected it to be.Perhaps, they should have just focused on the time travel aspect, because that was done brilliantly. Fusing it with Juan Severino Mallari’s story and excessive supernatural elements ruined what could have been an amazing time-travel historical film. The foundation was already there! It would’ve created something truly impressive and groundbreaking, until… the poor execution of the story’s very ambitious plot.Also, the dialogues were clunky. Many of the conversations between characters who are supposedly close to one another felt forced and awkward. An example is when Jonathan suddenly shouted at Lucas after the latter butted in on his conversation with Agnes. His shouting came out of nowhere, and it felt so forced. Sure, he was angry at Lucas, but I didn’t feel its emotional weight due to how forced it was. (I’m aware of the reason for Jonathan’s anger, it’s the clunky dialogue that’s the problem.) There are more instances like this throughout the film, and it really bothered me. The timing of the dialogues, as well as the choice of words, were really off.But despite my gripes with the film, I’m gonna give it three stars because it has some redeeming qualities. Among these are Piolo Pascual and JC Santos’ impeccable performances.I was absolutely impressed with how Piolo was able to portray three different characters while putting certain nuances to each of them. The three characters are really different from one another, and you could tell that based on their individual demeanors, personalities, and body languages, which Piolo fantastically depicted. I really hope he wins an award for this, because not many actors could pull this off.And JC Santos… man, he really deserves his Best Supporting Actor award!! Even though I was able to predict it easily, I had goosebumps when his character, Lucas, turned out to be the killer in the present day. JC pulled off the Jekyll and Hyde persona so well. He should do this type of role more often!Furthermore, the film did well when it comes to building suspense. Although it is not as scary as typical horror films, the jump scares were still frightening. Additionally, the score and sound effects were spectacular — they fitted every scene perfectly and greatly intensified the eerie atmosphere of the film. And the pacing was surprisingly good! In contrast to most long films, I wasn’t bothered with the runtime of this one. Most scenes were paced appropriately.Overall, disregarding my criticisms, I enjoyed watching this film. It had a lot of wasted potential, but it still gave me a nice cinematic experience.

Sorry to say this, but this is just a 130-minute-long glowed-up version of a Gabi ng Lagim episode. Staying awake was a struggle.Its astounding cinematography cannot salvage this film from the utter ludicrousness of the story. Its premise was interesting. After all, it was supposed to depict the Philippines' first serial killer, Fr. Juan Severino Mallari, a talented calligrapher-turned-murderer priest in Pampanga.Yet, it tried to outsmart its audience by hyping up a confused intergenerational Mallari curse. What came out was a mess littered with pathetically otiose jumpscares, lazy narrations, historical inaccuracies, overstretched fictionalization, and the implausibility of astral projection and time travel. To make matters worse, there were hints of transphobia, racism, and glorification of extrajudicial killings flying all over this film.JC Santos and his deranged act as a killer stood out in this film. And don't fret; that "twist" was given away in the first 15 minutes. Gloria Diaz was great. Piolo Pascual succeeded in crafting three different personas. All weren't enough to make this good enough.

Came into this expecting to know more about the actual Fr. Mallari, but should've known from that title card that the movie was going to end up exactly how it did.The rare silver linings were how Kapampangan was spoken throughout the film and JC Santos' performance, but I agree with popular sentiments: it was promising but overambitious, which resulted in a half-baked film with visual jumpscares that looked like TikTok filters.It also felt like the crew involved hated its future audience, getting ahead of themselves with "pa-woke" references and poor depiction of a LGBTQ character. I know the movie was about folk spirituality gone awry, but I guess I just expected more compassion from a movie related to religion.What a waste of a talented cast only to end up in a film that didn't know what to do with them.

No matter what other people say, i think this is a great horror filipino film I have ever watched. The way they infused and inspiration in filipino history and meshed it with filipino folklore and catholic saints to make it a theme over a theme was smooth. Writers have really sewn these together and made such a good horror film. Would also commend how Piolo depicted 3 different characters becoming slowly insane was something I did not expect at all. All the more, it was well executed; would watch again.

This film may had left a lot of things to be desired but I liked it. It has tons of jump scares (and I liked it that way, I guess) and for that, it somehow deserves some kind of appreciation, I guess. However, I felt that the other elements, particularly the time-travelling (or astral projection) part, were so underutilized because I felt that maybe this angle might have been used more to drive the story forward (it would have been fun to see more time altering consequences here). Also, it would have been more fun if the body count was a little bit higher, I guess. To add to the things that were left a lot to be desired, the ending fell flat for me, when the main character in the 2023 timeline ended up doing the exact things he was trying to prevent. Like dude (can't believe I share a name with the character), really now? Even your ancestors were disappointed.

Mallari is a good thriller film if you are craving some thrills. It gives adequate tension for most scenes, with entertaining plot twists for everyone watching.However, it suffered from bad writing and dumb choices. There was an attempt for a relatability in Father Mac's character, but it was too much it feels shoved into the film. Wonder if they paid license from Sueisha and Pierrot for that character that is just used for comedic relief. The marketing of the film is waaay waay off the actual film plot. It tried to incorporate a lot of elements: family, isekai, love, occult, Philippine folklore, and common horror tropes but executed quite badly. It was a clickbait/watchbait to say it is a film about Severino Mallari, but more of a fictionalized character of him (adding the Disclaimer about using St. Bartholomew as a plot device didn't help at all). The music is too much to aid with horror; it helped me anticipate the jumpscares.There is also a missed opportunity in painting the moon red for trying to tie it into blood moon as well, you know, when blood is involved here.But Piolo and JC Santos carried the film. They both provided some wide range of character. They somehow saved the film. I can also see Piolo in Melvil Poupaud. He somehow styles like him and has aged well.In short, Mallari is like me, quite confusing to discern its main purpose because it went off-tangents and digressions.

okay im gonna brain dump cause im writing this at 2 amAlright, this was pretty ok.It wasn't bad by any means, but this movie tried waaaay too hard to be scary. Too many cheap jump scares and the sound design ruined some of the moments. Some of the cgi was horrible too and I wish they used practical effects instead. Speaking of effects, the gore in this movie was weird. It's like they're not afraid to be graphic but they're also not showing how graphic the kills are? Then there's the plot. Lots of misplaced exposition and unanswered questions. Unanswered questions are a good thing but the questions we really needed answers to were never answered. Despite all of these, Mallari had a lot of things going for it. Piolo was great, JC was great, I bet Janella would've been great too if she was given more screen time. I respect their decision to add a more complicated twist to the material at hand, but this would've been better if it was a period piece and focused more on what happened back in 1812. Overall, a good watch but could've been better. What I like best about this movie is the fact that studios are giving stories like these a chance to get the big screen treatment. It gives me hope that this could open doors for more movies like this to get made.

An interesting premise wasted with mediocre story, cinematography and direction. The idea of a Filipino serial killer, and him being a priest, could have been a thought-provoking film about the hypocrisy of Catholicism that preaches good values but protects child molesters... instead we got a God-apologist film that attempts to nod toward "woke culture" by strawmanning a caricature of what conservatives think queerfolk are. Which honestly is very telling of the thinking of what the film is clearly intended for.…

Walang Diyos sa gabi.It’s refreshing to see Piolo Pascual do quadruple duty with his role as Father Juan Severino Mallari, Johnrey Mallari, and Jonathan Mallari de Dios. The film weaves three timelines, allowing the past and present to come full circle.Mallari goes beyond the historical account it is based on and adds a sense of supernatural and spiritual element to the mix, which in some parts worked, and some didn't. The story can go into familiar territory, settling with horror elements from the films in the past, and struggling to reach the film's full potential for the genre. However, much can be said about the film's magnificent and terrorizing score, cinematography, and production design. These aspects elevate the film even further, which is enough to make up for the story's shortcomings.

One of the most anticipated films of this year's MMFF is about the curious case of Father Severino Mallari, a real-life Filipino priest who is also the country's first-ever documented serial killer. What makes people even more excited is that this is lead actor #PioloPascual 's first horror film to date, after being tried and tested in romance/drama/comedy genres. This is among the final batch of films announced to be a part of the festival shortlist, which now has 2 entries more than its usual 8. In this film, Pascual plays three distinct characters in different time periods: Doctor Jonathan (present time), war documentarian Johnrey (1940s) and the serial killer Fr. Severino (1800s). Individually, these key characters all face the fears of their respective eras, while their paths converge in one hidden room of the Mallari mansion. It is delightful to watch Pascual step up his game in portraying the triple characters with distinct personalities, perhaps one of the most memorable performances in this festival. However, #JCSantos brings out the real surprise of this film and there's genuine terror in his character's ultimate reveal! If only the CGI effects were polished and convincing enough, then its horrific atmosphere may have been consistent. The film sure took a risk in mixing a lot of elements that could be too much to absorb in one sitting. Honestly, I would've wanted it to focus more on the killer priest and explore his psyche on a deeper level - his internal battles and the impact of his killings. The concept of an astral time travel could be saved on another film, the blood relation of the three leads may already be used to explain their connection. They could've used the time building up the crime-horror-folklore angles rather than explain all the sci-fi.Still, Mallari is a good attempt at elevating our taste in cinema. May this inspire more filmmakers to experiment in the horror genre.3.5 OUT OF 5½STORY - 0.7EXECUTION - 0.6CHARACTERIZATION - 0.8ENTERTAINMENT VALUE - 0.7LASTING IMPACT - 0.7

I think what makes many people disappointed at this film was because they assumed it'd be true to historical fact.I came in with no knowledge and expectations, so I loved the ride. It's amazing to think this is a local film. Great pacing, clear cut differentiation from each character/ timeline, and surprisingly the film was able to ease in sci-fi and supernatural concepts smoothly even if it was a bit out of left field. I honestly enjoyed the film, and it felt like going on a ride where you'd think it'll end soon, but turns out there's another part to explore and visit. It gave me the same amazement as I had with Parasite, with how the film felt like 3 movies in 1. So yeah, that was cool. I enjoyed it!

“’    ?”How far will you go for love? I believe this is the theme of the movie.Father Mallari is a real figure in Philippines history, the first documented serial killer in the country. The movie tells his story from the angle of love and madness. After some researches, I found that the real Father Mallari might have acted with love or he had mental issues.This movie is a fiction based on the real story of Father Mallari; it has a very mysterious background and I like the darkness it presented and how the story didn’t end with political correctness; however, the ending couldn’t have ended earlier.Nevertheless, there are too many jump scares (with unnecessarily too strong sound effect), which didn’t help pushing the plot forward and made it draggy.The acting range (and muscles) of Piolo are amazing; his has 4-style in the movie, if you watch close enough, there is a small detail for the style of Johnathan. Since Piolo has a mole near his left ear, to further differentiate the style of Johnrey and Johnathan, his mole was removed (likely by CG) when he plays Johnathan.JC Santos is really outstanding, he definitely stole the spotlight.The buildup of atmosphere is great, technical aspects are pretty impressive like visual effect, lighting and scores. However, editing seems to be another issue. For example, the scene where Father Mallari just returned home and almost encountered Johnrey and Johnathan, had repeated 3-time in the movie. Is it really necessary or audiences would be that absent-minded?I’m not sure whether relatively jumpy editing is the storytelling style of Director Cabrido, because his last movie      also has this issue.

Jusko ang panget. As in ang panget. Nasayangan ako sa 300 na binayad ko jusko talaga. Jusko!!!!! Kakairita kasi nag-expect ako kasi sabi maganda daw ganon, hype na hype pero ayon SOBRANG PANGET!!!!pakagulo ng story!!! Serial killer bigla naging werewolf tas may manananggal pa. Pinagsama sama ba naman lahat sa iisang movie, ayon ang kalat as fuck!!! Jusko feel ko mas okay to kung ginawa na lang nilang crime/thriller, hindi yung horror tas yung elements eh mga gamit na gamit na ng mga previous horror films ganon.Panget ng dialogue!! Panget ng delivery. May mga pilit na pilit magtagalog, tas may pilit din mag spanish. Jusko naman. Magagaling naman yung actors on their own pero bat ganon kapag magkakasama sila sa isang scene, ang panget. Panget ng directing, in short. Panget din ng vfx. Ang low effort. Natatawa ko sa mga films na shinushoot ni johnrey circa 1940s tapos ang framerate ay 60fps tapos pinatungan lang ng film scratches na filter. Jusko oh. Dinadaan sa booming sound fx yung jump scares, hindi naman talaga nakakatakot jusko. Wala ring build-up, hindi ka on edge ganon. Panget pa ng cgi sa mga multo. Naubos ata ang budget kay papa p.Isa pa, set sa pampanga toh, so expected na may kapampangan dialogue pero kakatawa kasi sobrang rare, parang siniksik lang ganon, masabi lang na kapampangan sila, napaka unnatural ng dating.Ayon pa pala, walang chemistry yung mga actors, esp si papa p at janella at elisse. Parang pilit na pilit yung relationship. Ewan shuta mas may chemistry pa ata si papa p at gloria diaz.Ang ambitious ng movie na toh, parang ang daming gustong talakayin na topics pero sa sobrang dami, ayon, underdeveloped lahat. Dat kase isa isa lang!!! Kung ginawa nyo na lang sana tong criticism ng church, baka mas okay pa.1 star kasi ok naman yung score, lalo yung sa ending. Sadyang panget lang ng lahat. Dinaan lang sa color grading eh. Bat ganto mga movie ngayon, puro aesthetics lang ata, kulang sa substance at ang gulo as fuck ng plot.Anyway, kung gusto nyo ng magandang horror film na about sa religion, panurin nyo na lang yung seklusyon. Creepy as fuck pa di tulad nito na mema lang.

(no context) the film is so good to the point that Im never eating BALUT AGAIN. Mallari is hands down one of the best Filipino films I've ever seen. The cinematography is crazy especially in the smooth transitions, with lighting and lines used. The film showcased into the nuanced relationship between religion, kulam, hierarchy, and also shows on how mental illness was once a taboo topic (till now lol). the story of the original juan severino from 1812, a 1946 Mallari who documents the post-WWII era through film, and a present-day Mallari doctor desperately searching for a cure for his fiancee's future illness. Piolo Pascual played all three Mallaris (fucking goated). A must watch! Dont forget to bring lotion and tissues

The storyline cleverly deceives you into believing that its plot is predictable, allowing you to anticipate scenes and revelations. However, the meticulous crafting of every detail ensures that, despite the apparent predictability, the execution remains so well-done that you'll still find yourself shocked and frightened. The film achieves this without unnecessarily complicating the narrative, maintaining its effectiveness in delivering surprises and scares."Mallari" masterfully employs a multi-sensory approach, seamlessly blending visuals and sound to provoke a powerful emotional response from the audience. The effectiveness of the musical scoring becomes evident as it skillfully crafts a suspenseful and frightening atmosphere, enhancing the impact of jump scares and intensifying the overall horror experience.The cast delivered compelling portrayals of their characters, infusing depth and authenticity that kept the audience engaged. Despite the anticipation of impending jump scares, their performances were so effective that even when expected, the audience found themselves screaming in response to the well-executed moments of shock.Contrary to the typical ending associated with this theme, where the protagonist usually finds redemption or breaks free from the negative thread, "Mallari" takes a different approach. The film allows the protagonist to embrace the path of becoming the villain, seemingly without learning from the events of the story, succumbing to darkness. This unexpected twist left a lasting impression, showcasing an innovative narrative where the conventional expectations are skillfully subverted, making the storytelling more impressive in its well-outlined and unconventional trajectory.Hats off to the Mallari Team for creating an outstanding film that truly deserves international recognition. Kudos to everyone involved!

A Mix of Hill House and Insidious in a Filipino Film.Yes. You’ve read that right. If you liked the two media I have mentioned, I’m sure you’d love Mallari just as much as I did. It had the perfect amount of jumpscares (which I liked a lot). But in my head, a good horror movie is more than just its jumpscares. It has to have a plot. And this movie had. I loved everything about this film regardless of the complaint of the internet on that one particular reveal/scene. To me, that scene added up everything and completely made sense. Undoubtedly, Piolo is already a really good actor and he delivered in this film. This is honestly the latest Filipino horror film that I genuinely enjoyed. Actually, the latest horror film (including films produced in Hollywood). It had a hint of hill house and insidious, which are two horror favorites of mine so I was grinning the whole film as I loved and is amazed by our bahaviors.

piolo pascual covered in blood with a moustache:

- mallari is a horror + time-travel story about a doctor, Jonathan, who (spoiler alert!!) dreamt his girlfriend will be dying, and he began his search of what made his great-great grandmother live a very, very long life to the point that there was no document of her death. the storytelling is very intelligent, piolo pascual playing 3 different roles in 3 different eras - second as Jonathan's old uncle and documentarist, Johnrey, who sacrificed himself in attempt to stop evil, and lastly as Fr. Severino who used to be very kind but ended up committing murders for his mother to live long. it's such a good watch, no dead scenes, also with jc santos, playing as Lucas, Jonathan's friend who was the killer in the present time!! i just hated that Jonathan killed him, but then ended up digging the grave of Johnrey to get the evil creature and pass it to his girlfriend, Agnes (played by janella salvador) making her a monster. he just put his uncle's sacrifice to waste!! what a stupid man... and not to mention, Agnes did not approve it, he only forced it to her. good thing, their relationship is not the same after, that's a good ending.

A familiar yet refreshing take on Filipino horror.Mallari served as the frontrunner for last year’s MMFF months before the festival. Trailers were good and promotions were good as well, but what surprised me is the difference between the final film and these promotional materials. I was expecting Mallari to be Psychological Thriller or a slasher film but it was meddled with paranormal and time travel. You can already pinpoint who the killer is in the first 30 minutes of the film, which is a bummer. JC Santos gave a splendid performance but his character and the twist of the story could be done better. Magulo yung first act, it felt like marami silang gustong ilagay sa marrative. Lines were cringy and walang tao sa totoong buhay na ganon mag salita. The film also had unnecessary jumpscares na walang purpose sa story, very Filipino horror movie core.The second and the last act is where the story started to take ita shape and form. I was glued down to my seats with what I was watching. Magulo ang simula pero natahi nila nang maayos ang lahat ng elemento sa dulo which is what made me like this film despite its issues. Piolo Pascual showed how great he was in his craft. Sa pelikulang ito makikita mo kung bakit sought after si Piolo. Janella Salvador was also great in this movie, she can be the queen of filipino horror movies. Sound design and the set designs were my favorite, dito mo makikitang pinaghandaan at may malaking budget ang palabas na ito.Mallari has some of the elements of a bad and cringey horror movies but it also has refreshing takes on a newer form of horror and storytelling that uses a lore to expound on a subject matter.

Perhaps the most surprising aspect of Mallari is how the director Derick Cabrido managed to weave together a staggering amount of narrative threads and somehow still ended up with a cohesive story. Although the same thing cannot be said about its many thematic layers that often felt convoluted and reactionary, there is something to be admired (or at least respected) with how textually rich Cabrido aims his film to be.Albeit inferred only through the choice of time periods (1818/1948/2018), Mallari succeeds in tracing a historical and cultural perspective on the Duterte drug war–that of a messianic figure (Duterte/Fr. Mallari) assuming the role of both judge and executioner of perceived "plagues" of society (the sinful/addicts)–and clearly demonstrates why this is problematic and is ultimately an act of self-preservation. The film takes a firm stance against mass murder, especially when it is enacted by the elites, and in the current Filipino socio-political climate this sentiment is well-appreciated.However, Mallari's portrayal of folk religion/mythology vis-a-vis Christianity is rather questionable. On one hand the film explores its anti-colonial capacity, that its integration into a Western notion of Christianity did not necessarily result into assimilation; indeed, through sinister shots littered with religious figurines (rooted in pagan worship) and the psychological corruption of Fr. Mallari's morals, the film shows that folk traditions' effects and influences have stood the test of time and could even be argued as the primary feature through which Filipinos practice modern Christianity.On the other hand, however, Mallari is still unable to resist the hegemonic assumptions that these folk practices are inherently evil; they may be anti-colonial but they're just as bad, maybe even worse. They function mainly to bolster the film's hypothesis—that evil is the primary component of the world and that everything else exist only in relation to it.This argument is most explicitly shown through the construction of Casa Mallari as a liminal space, where different temporal (past, present, future) and existential (living and non-living) realities converge. This is also the reason why the scares, although seemingly imitating the effect of sudden shock, are deliberately designed to evoke diminishing affective returns; fear is not an anomaly in the film's diegesis but is rather the norm, further supporting the essentialist view of the world and humanity as evil.And although this position works within the confines of the horror genre in which Mallari operates, I remain not fully sold on such bleak and defeatist attitude. I'd rather believe that there exist other "manlalakbays" (time travelers) with the capacity to intervene and put an end to this cycle of violence.

Piolo Pascual has proven why he is still at the top of his game. He has departed from the romantic heartthrob roles and has taken on more challenging and diverse characters than we usually see him in. In "Mallari," he portrays three related characters across different generations. I enjoyed the diversity in each character and how they all have different fates, showcasing various kinds of love. As Severino, the murderous priest with a malicious intent to kill the bad seed in his community and free his mother from a curse, Piolo is very convincing as a serial killer. The transition scene in the church, where he was being convinced by the Patron Saint Bartholomew, was just a chef’s kiss.As Johnrey, Piolo transitions into a man willing to do everything to rid himself of the curse. And as Jonathan, who was willing to do everything to save a loved one, Piolo was so good that you might want to express frustration for all the stupidity and recklessness he portrayed.The ending scene, where Piolo is facing the audience as if telling them that he will be hunting them for the night, is just brilliant. This is a one-of-a-kind Filipino horror movie.

The performances were mostly great as expected, it has a very interesting concept, and the vibe was surely creepy and effective. There were several intense moments that I genuinely enjoyed. The makeup, productions, and settings were amazing, as well. The visual effects did not look promising, but at least there were not a lot of it. There were some cheap scares, too, and wasted scenes that could have been really terrifying. Some people might also find the storytelling a little confusing, but I doubt anyone would not understand everything by the end. There were decent twists, but one major one was pretty predictable. But all in all, I know I haven't watched a lot of Tagalog movies in years, but this is one of, if not the best one I've seen in a while.2023 RankedHorror RankedTagalog Ranked

Though there was a tendency to use the cheapest of jump scares, I’d have to say that this was otherwise a fairly effective horror that was pretty decent at atmosphere building. It did drag a bit long at times and there was some confusion with it constantly switching time periods, but I can’t say it was a bad time.Piolo Pascual is a solidly charismatic lead.It was a pretty solid effort even if I wasn’t totally happy with its execution. I can definitely respect the film.

This film fumbles its creepy Filipino folklore concept. The concept had potential – a creepy urban legend stemming from a small provincial town, it was an interesting background.The film tries to be complex, weaving multiple narratives and timelines together, delving into astral projects and whatnot. However, this complexity ends up muddying the story instead of enriching it. It feels like the writer bit off more than they could chew, lacking the clear vision needed to pull off a compelling horror or thriller.The tension and suspense, crucial ingredients for any horror film, are noticeably absent. The overall storytelling, from pacing to camerawork, shot selections and editing choices fail to build any real sense of unease, suspense or anticipation; falling short of the genre's demands.With a tighter focus, a clearer narrative structure, and a director with a stronger grasp of the genre, "Mallari" could have been a genuinely scary and unsettling experience. As it stands, it's a forgettable mess.

horrible. so dumb and annoying, i'm not kidding when i say i was frowning throughout and considered walking out within 30 minutes into this. one of those films i knew instantly i wouldn't like it in the prologue and title card, and was so deeply disappointed at having been conned by that synopsis. it's not a period psychological horror about religion and mental illness, which is what that description implies, but so much bullshit with astral projection and time travelling (you can't be fucking kidding me....) jump scares and spirits zooming into the camera. it addresses nothing about spanish colonialism, christianity, or the locals, but rings through the same cycle about the ~ugly poors~ and lower class being practitioners of evil and the dark arts. wow... okay, groundbreaking and sooo progressive. of course. but what i absolutely loathed and consider super juvenile in horror filmmaking were the jump scares and sound design. i HATED the way sound was used in this. disgusting, cheap, no finesse or subtlety, the kind of thing writers and directors with no creativity use to spook the audience cos they have no talent crafting an atmospheric horror with the background and environment of its characters. came back home and discussed it a lot and everything we talked about just got me angrier, seeing how dumb this film was. a waste of my time and money.

The dialogue is pandering. I consider the portrayal of the trans character problematic because there is a greater focus on their perceived immorality compared to the other victims of Mallari. The servants are the villains that the wealthy master needs to defeat.There is a love for the horror genre with homages to psycho, Rosemary's baby, the Innocents. A greater emphasis is on trauma similar to the works of Mike Flanagan. I think the story is a combination between midnight mass and haunting of Hill house.Piolo Pascual convincingly portrays three different roles. Elisse Joson's mid Atlantic accent was a surprising detail that definitely sets her character in that time and place.

This was a really good film. It shows three perspectives of three different characters played by Piolo Pascual. The nice visual effects were really nice, and I was not expecting the quality to be THAT good. Byfar the BEST Filipino film I’ve seen.It boasts a captivating plot intricately linked to Philippine history and urban legend. The commendable acting skills of all characters significantly contribute to the film’s appeal. The pacing strikes a perfect balance—neither too fast nor too slow, preventing viewers from experiencing boredom, or confusion.Regrettably, the downside lies in the inclusion of unnecessary jump scares, creating an abrupt disruption in the flow of the film. This drawback proves to be a significant dent in the overall quality of an otherwise promising story.Despite this setback, it’s important to note that “Mallari” still stands as a commendable horror film, especially when compared to the usual offerings in the Philippine horror genre. Its compelling plot, historical ties, and the commendable performances of the cast elevate it above many counterparts, making it a worthwhile watch for enthusiasts of the genre.
OVERALL 10/10 MAS NINDOT IF SA SINEHAN GYUD LANTAWON THE FOLKLORES, MUSIC, CINEMATOGRAPHY, ACTING, PLOT, EVERTHING WAS ON POINT A MUST WATCH MOVIE

โอ้โหนี่ฉันถ่อมาถึงไอคอนสยามเพื่อดูหนังแบบนี้อ่ะนะ  บาปกว่านั้นคือเพื่อนเกาะไหล่มาดูด้วย ไอเราใช้เอ็มพาสก็เสียดายแค่ค่ารถกับเวลา แต่เพื่อนก็คือเสียค่าตั๋วฉ่ำๆ 180…อ่ะพูดกันตามตรงวัตถุดิบมันก็มีศักยภาพพอจะเป็นหนังสนุกอยู่ ชนบท เรื่องดำมืดในตระกูล นักท่องกาลเวลา ผีเอเชียใต้ชายคาโบถส์คริสต์ การถูกกดทับของชนชั้นล่างที่ถูกปลดปล่อยมาในรูปปีศาจ แต่คือล้มเหลวในการปรุงให้สนุกมากๆ… เทคนิคภาพเกรดบีแบบหนังเด็กมัธยมเมื่อ 10 ปีก่อน ความเล่าเป็นก้อนๆพอถึงจุดพีคก็ตัดฉับไปเล่าก้อนใหม่โดยที่จุดพีคของแต่ละก้อนก็อ้อมแอ้มๆ ถ่ายแบบหลบๆกล้าๆกลัวๆ ความไม่เมคเซนส์ของตัวละคร เหนืออื่นใดคือยืดเยื้อมากๆทำทำไมตั้ง 2 ชั่วโมง 9 นาที จะเล่าหลายเส้นเรื่องแต่จุดที่มันตัดกันก็คือฉายซ้ำไปซ้ำมา ทีเดียวก็รู้เรื่องแล้วคุณพี่! โว๊ะ!ซีนที่รู้สึกว่าอ่ะพอได้มีแค่ซีนที่แม่เต้นรำกับหลวงพ่อเคลื่อนกล้องพริ้วไหวดี กับ ซีนพระเอกไปขุดผีแล้วบรรพบุรุษมาคุยด้วย(ซึ่งถ้าหนังมันเล่าดีๆนี่ว่าทัชใจคนได้เลยนะ แต่อันนี้มันเล่าแย่เลยรู้สึกเสียดาย)มาดูถึงกลางเมืองก็ไม่วายเจออะไรแย่ๆ คราวนี้เจอลุงไอฉ่ำทั้งเรื่อง ไอขนาดนี้เป็นหนูคงเดินออกจากโรงแร๊วอ่ะ กับ นางคอมเมนต์นางด่าตลค. ด่าโง่บ้างนู่นบ้างนี่บ้างโอ๊ยเก็บไว้ในใจมั่งเห๊อะะะะ ก็หลงคิดไปไกลว่าจะไปถึง Impetigore ดูฆ่าเวลายังไม่ได้เลย!

Movie: มัลลารี ตำนานเชือด โลกสะท้าน | Mallariคะเเนนจากเรา : 7 /10คะเเนนจาก Rotten Tometoes  : -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Review Session  - รีวิว Mallari แรงบันดาลใจจากเรื่องจริง..สู่ภาพยนตร์สยองของฟิลิปปินส์ ที่ได้รับเลือกเข้าฉายในเมโทรมะนิลาฟิล์มเฟสติวัล ครั้งที่ 49 Mallari - ตำนานเชือดโลกสะท้าน ที่ครั้งนี้ทาง Warner Bros. Thailand คว้าตัวนักแสดงหนุ่มอารมณ์ดีอย่าง คุณหยวน กวินรัฏฐ์ ยศอมรสุนทร มาให้เสียงเป็นทั้งหมด 3 ตัวด้วยกันได้แก่ บาทหลวงมัลลารี , นักทำสาคดี จอห์นเรย์ มัลลารี และ คุณหมอ โจนาธาน มัลลารี เป็นหนังที่สยองขวัญที่ระทึกมากๆเลยครับพล็อตเรื่องมีความโดดเด่นมากๆ และตัวแอดนั้นชื่นชอบมากคือการหยิบเอาคนสามไทม์ไลน์มาเชื่อมโยงกัน แต่เรื่องราวนั้นกับเชื่อมกันได้อย่างลงตัว มีแค่บางฉากเท่านั้นที่ตัดสลับแบบฉึบฉับไปบ้าง ตรงนี้อาจทำผู้ชมนั้น งง ง่วยได้ แต่โดยรวมแล้วก็พอจะเข้าใจง่ายอยู่ครับ สำหรับเารเดินเรื่องของหนังเรื่องนี้ แต่ที่เด่นๆเลยก็ขอยกให้ความระทึกขวัญเนี้ยล่ะครับที่ให้อารมณ์เหใอนเราได้ชมหนังผีต่างจังหวัดเลยล่ะครับ ซึ่งฉากระทึกๆนั้นตัวหนังมีเยอะมากๆ แถมทำคนดูขนลุกขนพองกันได้แน่นอนครับ ส่วนฉากที่คิดว่าน่ากลัวนั้นขอยกให้ฉากในบ้านเนี้ยล่ะครับ รับประกันเลยว่าสยองอย่างแน่นอน และตัวหนังยังได้ดัดแปลงมาจากเรื่องจริงอีกมันเลยค่อนข้างที่จะน่าสนใจมากเลยล่ะครับนอกจากความสยองของหนังแล้วตัวหนังยังมีเรื่องราวของทูตผีปีศาจอีกด้วยครับ แต่ตัวแอดนั้นไม่รู้จริงๆว่ามันคือตัวอะไร หรือมันอาจจะเป็นผีพื้นบ้านของฟิลิปปินส์รึเปล่า แต่ก็ทำออกมาได้อย่างน่ากลัวและหลอนมากๆเลยล่ะครับ และในช่วงท้ายตัวหนังยังมีตอนจบที่หักมุมแบบสุดๆอีกด้วยครับส่วนด้านของนักแสดงนั้นก็ทำออกมาได้ดีครับ ดูมีมิติ และน่าติดตามพอสมควรเลยล่ะ และใครที่อยากรู้สัมผัสประสบการณ์ความสยองที่ดัดแปลงมาจากเรื่องจริงฆาตกรต่อเนื่องคนแรกในประวัติศาสตร์ของฟิลิปปินส์ก็ไม่ควรพลาดครับกับ Mallari มัลลารี ตำนานเชือดโลกสะท้านฉายเเล้ววันนี้ในโรงภาพยนต์ทั่วประเทศ

Father Severino: Panganay na mama's boy forever Johnrey: The rationale middle childJonathan: The super spoiled na bunsong sabog ang priorities at decision-making sa buhayI honestly thought it was just a historical fiction drama with a slight side of horror and thriller, but boy I was surprised. It made me question my sanity and decision making for a good minute. Why did I even watch this past 3 in the morning. Overall, I really liked the technicality of this film [except that manananggal scene that came from nowhere]. The scoring gave justice to how the film should feel like.

I went into "Mallari" with a mixture of excitement and skepticism because of how well-received it was by Filipino viewers on social media. Regretfully, the film's execution left me feeling disappointed, and my expectations were not fulfilled. To bring the story to its best, the screenplay in particular needs to be significantly revised.On the one hand, the film's artistic vision is praiseworthy. It is creative and promising that the authors chose to examine several incarnations of the Mallari family in diverse eras. But the execution is inadequate. It's challenging to fully immerse yourself in the characters and their struggles because of the story's rambling dialogue and pacing.Despite being a crucial part of the movie, the big reveal feels hurried and doesn't have the emotional impact it needs. The final choice made by the protagonist, which is supposed to be a pivotal moment in the narrative, is disappointing and has no lasting effect. Additionally, there is no tension or surprise because the criminal killer's identity is revealed right away. Furthermore, the movie's depiction of Mallari's deeds and killings is a little sanitized, which lessens the story's overall impact. The final product does not justify the audience's reaction to the story, nor does it fully realize its complexity. It was a failure all around. Although it had promise, the narrative required a lot of work and changes. The morality of Fr. could have been the subject of the film. Mallari and how his actions' effects were still troublesome. The topic of murder and why it shouldn't be accepted or exalted could have been covered.Sayang!Props to JC Santos tho!
